This is for all you Socialist/ Marxist Sycophants on this thread , Hitler Was a Socialist Who Learned from Karl Marx. Let‚Äôs hear from his own words:


Hitler on Marxism
‚ÄúNational Socialism derives from each of the two camps the pure idea that characterizes it, national resolution from bourgeois tradition; vital, creative socialism from the teaching of Marxism.‚Äù ‚Äì 

January 27, 1934, interview with Hanns Johst in Frankforter Volksblatt

Hitler on Teaching Socialism
‚ÄúThere is a difference between the theoretical knowledge of socialism and the practical life of socialism. People are not born socialists, but must first be taught how to become them.‚Äù ‚Äì 

October 5, 1937, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Capitalism
‚ÄúIn those countries, it is actually capital that rules; that is, nothing more than a clique of a few hundred men who possess untold wealth and, as a consequence of the peculiar structure of their national life, are more or less independent and free. They say: ‚ÄòHere we have liberty.‚Äô By this they mean, above all, an uncontrolled economy, and by an uncontrolled economy, the freedom not only to acquire capital but to make absolutely free use of it. That means freedom from national control or control by the people both in the acquisition of capital and in its employment. This is really what they mean when they speak of liberty. These capitalists create their own press and then speak of the ‚Äòfreedom of the press.‚Äô In reality, every one of the newspapers has a master, and in every case this master is the capitalist, the owner. This master, not the editor, is the one who directs the policy of the paper. If the editor tries to write other than what suits the master, he is ousted the next day. This press, which is the absolutely submissive and characterless slave of the owners, molds public opinion. Yes, certainly, we jeopardize the liberty to profiteer at the expense of the community, and, if necessary, we even abolish it.‚Äù ‚Äì 

December 10, 1940, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Socialism
‚ÄúSocialism as the final concept of duty, the ethical duty of work, not just for oneself but also for one‚Äôs fellow man‚Äôs sake, and above all the principle: Common good before own good, a struggle against all parasitism and especially against easy and unearned income. replies.author: @Ugly_German_Truths
replies.text:
+Jacob Furrow
"The US was founded to protect the minority"
Well yes it was... to protect the wealthy minority of landed almost-gentry like Washington, Jefferson and the majority of the founding fathers. That is directly confirmed in the history behind institutions like the Senate (originally senators were elected by the state governments not the population, that came only pretty recently in 1920 or so... and to give even the smallest, least populous state the same 2 senators meant the interests of their wealthy upper class that had the most drive and ability to engage in politics were protected from simple strongarming by the bigger and more populous states!) or the electoral college (when the constitution was written it was expensive to take weeks off to travel to Washington and vote on the election results as part of the college of electors, so who would mostly be sent to do this job for the states? Again the rich and powerful who could afford to be absent for a few months at a time, unlike the craftsmen or small farmers, a situation that was even worse in the less developed south that on average would be the farthest from D.C. amongst the states until they at least crossed the Mississippi 45ish years after the declaration of independence and about 30ish years after the constitution was passed in the continental congress.).

replies.text: "It's important to remember that the constitutional system was not designed in the first place to defend the rights of people. Rather, the rights of people had to be balanced, as Madison put it, against what he called 'the rights of property'. Well of course, property has no rights: my pen has no rights. Maybe I have a right to it, but the pen has no rights. So, this is just a code phrase for the rights of people with property. The constitutional system was founded on the principle that the rights of people with property have to be privileged; they have rights because they're people, but they also have especial rights because they have property. As Madison put it in the constitutional debates, the goal of government must be "to protect the minority of the opulent against the majority". That's the way the system was set up." - Noam Chomsky

@thinhvo3893 You're right. Socialism is not (necessarily) when the government does stuff. It's when the state owns the means of productions. 

You're wrong when you say that what Hitler did was Socialism of the right. There is no such thing. Right ideologies need to have some kind of a market economy, the more left leaning it is, the more collective control is over the means of production. So when it comes down to the market, if a private can not decide what's best for his own business, then it can't be a right ideology.

The state did control the means of production. By "gleichschaltung" of the economy. The individual can not act upon the interest of his own and has to operate for the state, as an organ of the state.

I think its stupid to associate certain ideologies with left or right. The whole idea of left and right is wrong and an unproductive way of telling what an ideology is.

A better way is by sorting it by how the  state controls the economy and simultaneously look in what kind of system of power the country runs. From democracy to Republic, then monarchy and lastly totalitarianism. 

The conclusion is, there is nothing "right wing" about Hitler. As the nazi regime was totalitarianism, which simply can not exist under a "right wing" ideology.

replies.text:
@clearsky9051 "aborting a fetus with diagnosed Downs is most likely no eugenics" You do understand what eugenics is don't you? Eugenics is literally an ideology that proposes restricted breeding to CONTROL THE PURITY OF THE GENE POOL and harvest resources for the strongest most intelligent people. This was supported by people such as Roosevelt, Churchill, HG Wells, even Helen Keller who was herself blind. 
From the late 1800's to the current day Eugenics is still alive and well. In the US for example forced sterilisation was continued until at least 1963 in California for those deemed "unfit" to give birth.  Eugenics became a dirty word after Hitlers programs came to light. The whole ideology was repackaged and became "planned parenthood" 
The legalisation of abortion was nothing to do with feminist ranting, in fact abortion was legal in many places before feminism was even a buzzword. Abortion was a required outcome for  "purity of genes. The belief behind this was that only poor people, the unintelligent and the sexually promiscuous would use such services. This I would suggest has been well and truly born out. It's not wealthy educated people who use abortion clinics. If I'm correct, as I don't have the figures to hand, abortion is predominantly used by, in the US at least, primarily black, poor, and uneducated people.  This was the demographic abortion was aimed at.
To suggest abortion is primarily used to abort a foetus with Downs Syndrome is pretty weird, the physical or mental capacities of most aborted foetuses is not even known. It requires specific tests to check for Downs Syndrome in unborn babies, most of which are unaffordable for those getting abortions and given anyway only in specific cases where there is a genuine risk. I.e age, previous children, family history etc.
I suggest you do some reading on the ideology of Eugenics, the aims of Eugenics and how Eugenics has evolved to ease pressure on the welfare state and other resources. 
NYC latest ruling on late term abortions is not merely a pandering to "female empowerment" it's the final chance to choose whether a baby will be a burden or a value to society, especially for those pregnant mothers who did not have pre birth scans or tests for possible disabilities.

replies.author: @matthewkopp2391
replies.text:
MajorLeague I believe the opposite. Real Marxist idea would simply mean worker ownership of the means of production and a free association of these producers.

This idea is more acheivable in the USA or Germany than it is in developing nation if a working class was more conscious of the paradigm.

Social Democracy was designed by Bismarck as a response to thwart the development of socialism. It does so by making the urgency a mute point, meaning if the state is supplying the needs that workers want they are less likely to try to find ways in which they could collectively own the means of production.

I also was trying to illustrate what Marx meant by class consciousness. Contrary to popular belief it was not merely ‚Äúoppressor oppressed‚Äù paradigm. It was developing enough consciousness so the absurdity of the paradigm is abandoned altogether.

In other words it is a Hegelian synthesis of worker and bourgeoisie/capitalist/employer specifically because the workers are employing themselves.

It is much more realistic for educated workers of the USA or Germany to have access to capital, knowledge and resources to implement a cooperative solution than it would be for workers in a third world country.

The problem I see in the USA especially is clear, the working class is perpetually mystified watching things like FOX news.

In fact I watched FOX today and they multiple times conflated the majority of Democrats who are neoliberal with ‚Äúradical socialism‚Äù. This is effective propaganda rendering any rational discussion nearly impossible. Because the conflate neoliberalism with social democracy with socialism and communism.

The failure of the left in the USA is specifically because the left is not informed by Marxism, and does not offer simple pragmatic Marxist solutions.

A pragmatic Marxist solution would be to unite and prepare workers to take over the means of production. Have you seen many pragmatic proposals of this sort?

This could happen in many sectors of the economy. In Germany for example bank depositors are earning nearly Zero interest. So why not create cooperative banks? There is a health insurance problem in the USA why not create cooperative insurance. There is an education affordability problem why not create a cooperative education system. There is a low wage problem in things like food service why not create more cooperative franchises and grocery stores.

replies.author: @RoccoMariaAnders
replies.text:
@kruczyzmora2885 
Thank you for being open minded about this.

Now, authoritarian governments are not an inherently socialist thing, despite what many americans believe. Socialism just requires collective ownership of industry, meaning everybody in a workplace is considered an owner of that workplace, unlike in capitalism where workplaces are owned and controlled by only a few bosses or shareholders. This doesn't require a strong state necessarily. There are in fact many socialists that identify as libertarians or anarchists, or who want a free market to distribute goods instead of a central govt body.
Some famous anti-authoritarian socialists include Noam Chomsky, Peter Kroptkin, Rosa Luxembourg and Nestor Makhno.

I wanted to clear this up. Being pro-authority doesn't mean you're pro-socialism, and vice versa.

If that were the case, chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet would be a socialist, and he was an outspoken anti-communist who shaped his countries after neoliberal super-capitalist principles.

Hitler also had a lot of negative things to say about the economics of the left in his book "Mein Kampf". Chapter 2 was literally about how marxism, the economic framework that birthed socialism, is a jewish plot to destroy the world and ignores fundamental parts of humanity.
In the same chapter he talked about how social democrats are manipulative crooks with an ideology not grounded in reality.

And as this video explained, the nazis did have a bunch of socialists in their party before they came to power, but they were purged in the "night of the long knifes".

The nazis were opposed to socialism AND the free market, since they thought both were a threat to their nationalist culture, so what they settled on was an authoritarian state capitalist/corporatist economy.

The other vids by this youtuber explained that a bit further.

The nazis were not socialist just because they were authoritarians, or because they had "socialist" in their name. That was merely a misnomer.
I think it's very good people like you are willing to learn. 

Thank you for listening. üëçüèº

replies.text:
@MrMadmaggot 
Using force doesn't make you an authoritarian.

If it was, that would mean capitalism is also authoritarian, since it took a ton of force from peasants, merchants and revolutionairies to move from feudalism to capitalism.

Do you think capitalism just appeared one day naturally, and the feudal lords and slave owners just gave up all their power to the factory owners and merchants?
No.
It took countless revolutions, revolts and civil wars to abolish feudalism and slavery and make way for the capitalist system.

Was the french revolution that birthed democracy authoritarian?
Was the american revolution that you dumb yanks glorify so much authoritarian?
Was the american civil war that abolished slavery authoritarian?

No they fucking weren't. And neither are the people that are arguing for a socialist revolution today.

And libertarian socialism is not an oxymoron. If anything, libertarian capitalism is. Anarcho-Capitalists literally believe people have a right to buy slaves, as long as its "voluntary". They are fine with abolishing democracy and the total subjugation of the individual to an unquestioned authority, as long as that authority calls itself a CEO or a shareholder instead of a politician.

Even Murray Rothbard admitted the word "libertarian" initially described left wing ideologies.

Real and consistent libertarianism can only exist where the economy is ruled by all, not by a wealthy elite or a dictatorial state.

Socialism aims to achieve real economic freedom for as many people as possible. Not this "libertarian capitalism" bullshit.

Hitler on Marxism

January 27, 1934, interview with Hanns Johst in Frankforter Volksblatt

Hitler on Teaching Socialism
‚ÄúThere is a difference between the theoretical knowledge of socialism and the practical life of socialism. People are not born socialists, but must first be taught how to become them.‚Äù ‚Äì 

October 5, 1937, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Capitalism
‚ÄúIn those countries, it is actually capital that rules; that is, nothing more than a clique of a few hundred men who possess untold wealth and, as a consequence of the peculiar structure of their national life, are more or less independent and free. That means freedom from national control or control by the people both in the acquisition of capital and in its employment. This is really what they mean when they speak of liberty. These capitalists create their own press and then speak of the ‚Äòfreedom of the press.‚Äô In reality, every one of the newspapers has a master, and in every case this master is the capitalist, the owner. This master, not the editor, is the one who directs the policy of the paper. If the editor tries to write other than what suits the master, he is ousted the next day. This press, which is the absolutely submissive and characterless slave of the owners, molds public opinion. December 10, 1940, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Socialism
‚ÄúSocialism as the final concept of duty, the ethical duty of work, not just for oneself but also for one‚Äôs fellow man‚Äôs sake, and above all the principle: Common good before own good, a struggle against all parasitism and especially against easy and unearned income. replies.author: @Counter-Intuitive
replies.text:
In the months after Hitler took power, SA and *Gestapo agents went from door to door looking for Hitler‚Äôs enemies. They arrested Socialists, Communists, trade union leaders, and others who had spoken out against the Nazi party* some were murdered. By the summer of 1933, the Nazi party was the only legal political party in Germany. Nearly all organized opposition to the regime had been eliminated. Democracy was dead in Germany.
*However, the assumption that because the word ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù appeared in the party‚Äôs name and socialist words and ideas popped up in the writings and speeches of top Nazis then the Nazis must have been actual socialists is naive and ahistorical. What the evidence shows, on the contrary, is that Nazi Party leaders paid mere lip service to socialist ideals on the way to achieving their one true goal: raw, right-wing totalitarian power*

Yes, the Nazis were indisputably Right-Wing

Sometimes the claim is bandied about that the Nazis were a left-wing party on economic questions, perhaps because the Nazis were called ‚ÄúNational socialists‚Äù. This is flatly and completely wrong and a form of pseudo-historiography. Here‚Äôs why:

The Nazi party was built on right-wing voters and a right-wing support base:

There are many disputes about the nature of Hitler‚Äôs voting base. What isn‚Äôt under dispute though is that prior to voting Nazi, Nazi voters voted for centre-right and far-right parties, or didn‚Äôt vote at all. Support for the Nazis¬†did not¬†come from disaffected left-wing or centre-left voters, but from right-wing voters frustrated with the existing parties of the right.

In my view this point alone is decisive. The meaning of right-wing and left-wing is not an ahistorical abstraction, it‚Äôs created by the behaviour of people and institutions. The right-wing citizens of Germany implicitly recognised the Nazis as right-wing by voting for them, case closed.

Read more about which parties Nazi voters defected from here:¬†https://gking.harvard.edu/files/gking/files/nazivp.pdf

2. The Nazis literally invented privatisation:

The Nazis were responsible for huge privatisation programs. The extent of their privatisations was enormous, but it was particularly vast when compared with other countries at the time, who were generally moving in the opposite direction. The privatisations of Nazi Germany may indeed have been the first mass privatisations of public property in history and included ‚ÄúSteel, mining, banking, shipyard, ship-lines, and railways.‚Äù More on how Nazis bucked historical trends by privatising when no one else was here:¬†http://www.ub.edu/graap/nazi.pdf

3. Nazi policies greatly increased income inequality:

Income inequality spiked under Hitler, as was observed even at the time. More here:¬†http://piketty.pse.ens.fr/files/capitalisback/CountryData/Germany/Other/Pre1950Series/RefsHistoricalGermanAccounts/Sweezy39.pdf

4. Capital as a share of factor income also spiked under Hitler, at the expense of wages:

Factor income describes the division between the factors of production, with land receiving rent, capital receiving profit and labour receiving wages. The capital share, or profit as a proportion of total income, increased by about 50% in Nazi Germany and was much higher than the US‚Äôs capital share at the time. See the below graph from¬†Capital in the Twenty-First Century¬†reproduced in a Jacobin article by Corey Robin:
I‚Äôm sorry if there‚Äôs not much in the way of Belles-lettres here. If I am blunt it is for a purpose. The Nazis were right-wing. Anyone who tells you otherwise is wrong, much in the same way it is wrong to say that the world is flat, six-thousand years old, or made of cheese.

Read the quote i posted from your own source, he redefined socialist.  He even said actual socialists aren't socialist, "I shall take Socialism away from the Socialists."  

This is what precludes naziism from socialism: "Nazism attempted to reconcile conservative, nationalist ideology with a socially radical doctrine. In so doing, it became a profoundly revolutionary movement‚Äîalbeit a largely negative one. Rejecting rationalism, liberalism, democracy, the rule of law, human rights, and all movements of international cooperation and peace, it stressed instinct, the subordination of the individual to the state, and the necessity of blind and unswerving obedience to leaders appointed from above. It also emphasized the inequality of men and races and the right of the strong to rule the weak; sought to purge or suppress competing political, religious, and social institutions; advanced an ethic of hardness and ferocity; and partly destroyed class distinctions by drawing into the movement misfits and failures from all social classes. Although socialism was traditionally an internationalist creed, the radical wing of Nazism knew that a mass base existed for policies that were simultaneously anticapitalist and nationalist. However, after Hitler secured power, this radical strain was eliminated." https://www.britannica.com/event/Nazism
You will note that from the definition of socialism (which i posted above as well and you haven't argued against) is: "Socialism, social and economic doctrine that calls for public rather than private ownership or control of property and natural resources. According to the socialist view, individuals do not live or work in isolation but live in cooperation with one another. Furthermore, everything that people produce is in some sense a social product, and everyone who contributes to the production of a good is entitled to a share in it. Society as a whole, therefore, should own or at least control property for the benefit of all its members." https://www.britannica.com/topic/socialism   
So what precludes Naziism from Socialism is that bit about rejecting human rights (contrary to the "... individuals do not live or work in isolation but live in cooperation with one another"), Inequality of men and races (contrary to the same part above, "...everyone who contributes to the production of a good is entitled to a share in it," and "Society as a whole, therefore, should own or at least control property for the benefit of ALL its members." (capitalization mine)),  and that last bit of the first quote about "Although socialism was traditionally an internationalist creed, the radical wing of Nazism knew that a mass base existed for policies that were simultaneously anticapitalist and nationalist. However, after Hitler secured power, this radical strain was eliminated."

Had it truely been an attack on all the wealthy of the German state then why were the Germans who were wealthy left alone, especially since they made up 75% of the wealthy? and you have provided no sources so again your claim of "It is a position within the contemporary context of the nazi movement which I have provided you from the mouth of the leader of the movement" doesn't hold water.

Nationalism isn't mutually exclusive with socialism, Fascism is. Its definitions shows as such; "Although fascist parties and movements differed significantly from one another, they had many characteristics in common, including extreme militaristic nationalism, contempt for electoral democracy and political and cultural liberalism, a belief in natural social hierarchy and the rule of elites, and the desire to create a Volksgemeinschaft (German: ‚Äúpeople‚Äôs community‚Äù), in which individual interests would be subordinated to the good of the nation."  Referring back again to the definition of socialism this doesn't fit as "...a belief in natural social hierarchy and the rule of elites..." is anathema to "Furthermore, everything that people produce is in some sense a social product, and everyone who contributes to the production of a good is entitled to a share in it."  Additionally "...the desire to create a Volksgemeinschaft (German: ‚Äúpeople‚Äôs community‚Äù), in which individual interests would be subordinated to the good of the nation" is not the same as "Society as a whole, therefore, should own or at least control property for the benefit of all its members." One is where its for the benefit of the STATE and the other is for the benefit of ALL ITS MEMBERS, this is easily demonstrated as potentially contradictory as what benefited the US state in the 1700s was the enslavement of blacks, or members of the US society yet did not benefit them.  Also, "Sounds like history will shit on that conjecture," you have to prove that statement as you are the one making an assertion and funnily enough all my above evidence proves the contrary. 

Finaly: "Can you support that Hitler was some bowlerhatted, educated capitalist who was well connected in Germany? Hitler even has the makings of a socialist leader, is my point. For those who contend his sympathies were with capitalists, how is it supported?" Straw man argument and red herring. Straw man since I never made such an assertion you are building a straw man to tear down (in fact I explicitly stated he used socialist and capitalist policies when they suited him politically to gain power) and red herring because the beginning part is irrelevant to him not being socialist.  Straw man: "Substituting a person‚Äôs actual position or argument with a distorted, exaggerated, or misrepresented version of the position of the argument." (https://www.logicallyfallacious.com/tools/lp/Bo/LogicalFallacies/169/Strawman-Fallacy)  Red herring: "Red herring is a kind of fallacy that is an irrelevant topic introduced in an argument to divert the attention of listeners or readers from the original issue. In literature, this fallacy is often used in detective or suspense novels to mislead readers or characters, or to induce them to make false conclusions." (https://literarydevices.net/red-herring/)

- Their "leitmotiv" is the class struggle.
- They reject private property.
- They are tremendously anti-capitalist.
- They seek the emancipation of women.
- They reject individualism.
- Extreme defense of the working class.

Nazism:

- They were nationalists.
- They didn't believe in the class struggle, in fact they were empowered by the bourgeoisie and Hitler promised to "destroy the parties of the class struggle" during his first speech as chancellor. 
- They defended private property.
- They weren't anti-capitalist.
- Women could only be two things: housewives and "children-makers".
- They defended individualism.
- Thet banned labor unions and the right to strike.

Yep, definitely they were socialist.

replies.author: @SaraSwank
replies.text:
MajorLeague The text (in spanish sorry):

Muchos defensores de la tesis de que la Alemania nazi era socialista sostienen que, aunque exist√≠a propiedad privada de los medios de producci√≥n, esta estaba supeditada al Estado, es decir, era meramente nominal. Esto no es cierto, como se√±alan Buchheim y Scherner (2006):

 ‚ùùLa propiedad privada en la industria del Tercer Reich es a menudo considerada una mera disposici√≥n nominal sin mucha sustancia. Sin embargo, eso no es correcto, porque las empresas, a pesar del racionamiento y actividades de licenciamiento del Estado, todav√≠a ten√≠an amplio alcance para dise√±ar sus propios perfiles de producci√≥n e inversi√≥n. Incluso con respecto a proyectos relacionados con la guerra, la libertad de contrataci√≥n se respet√≥ en general; en lugar de usar la fuerza, el Estado ofreci√≥ a las empresas una serie de opciones de contrato para elegir. Hab√≠a varios motivos detr√°s de esta actitud del r√©gimen, entre ellos la convicci√≥n de que la propiedad privada proporciona incentivos importantes para aumentar la eficiencia.‚ùû (pp. 390).

Las empresas privadas durante la Alemania nazi ten√≠an libertad para rechazar los proyectos estatales, sin ninguna consecuencia o sin temor a sufrir represalias o ser nacionalizadas. E incluso, en algunas ocasiones, como en el caso de Froriep GmbH, el Estado acataba las decisiones de las empresas privadas:

 ‚ùùLas empresas normalmente podr√≠an negarse a participar en un proyecto de inversi√≥n dise√±ado por el Estado, sin ninguna consecuencia. Hay bastantes casos en que lo hicieron, incluso despu√©s de la implementaci√≥n del plan de cuatro a√±os y el comienzo de la guerra, ambos considerados en algunas publicaciones como cruciales en la pol√≠tica econ√≥mica del r√©gimen. Y, de hecho, la ret√≥rica a veces pudo haberse vuelto m√°s agresiva despu√©s de 1936. Pero el comportamiento real del Estado nazi en las relaciones con las empresas privadas parece no haber cambiado, porque las empresas continuaron actuando sin ning√∫n tipo de temor a ser nacionalizadas o puestas de otra manera bajo una presi√≥n insoportable.

 As√≠, de Wendel, una empresa minera de carb√≥n, se neg√≥ a construir otra planta de hidrogenaci√≥n en 1937. En la primavera de 1939 IG Farben rechaz√≥ una solicitud del Ministerio de Econom√≠a para ampliar su producci√≥n de ray√≥n para el uso en neum√°ticos. Tampoco estaba preparado para invertir una cantidad sustancial en una tercera f√°brica en F√ºrstenberg/Oder de buna (caucho sint√©tico), aunque este era un proyecto de gran urgencia para el r√©gimen. Otro ejemplo interesante es el de Froriep GmbH, una empresa que produc√≠a m√°quinas para el armamento y las industrias relacionadas con la autarqu√≠a, que tambi√©n encontraron un mercado listo en el exterior. En la segunda mitad de la d√©cada de 1930 la demanda de los prop√≥sitos anteriores era tan alta que las exportaciones amenazaban con ser totalmente desplazadas. Por lo tanto, la compa√±√≠a planific√≥ una ampliaci√≥n de la capacidad, pero solicit√≥ al Reich que compartiera el riesgo otorgando un cr√©dito subsidiado y permitiendo cargas de depreciaci√≥n excepcionales para reducir su carga impositiva. Cuando la √∫ltima demanda no fue aceptada al principio, la empresa reaccion√≥ al negarse a invertir. Entonces, al final, el Estado se rindi√≥ por completo a las solicitudes de la empresa.‚ùû (Buchheim y Scherner, 2006, pp. 401-402).

Las empresas privadas actuaron con sus inversiones sabiendo que los nazis nunca implantar√≠an un sistema econ√≥mico socialista:

‚ùùEl comportamiento de las empresas en todos estos casos tambi√©n demostr√≥ que previeron la eventual reducci√≥n del intervencionismo y de la demanda estatal, que conducir√≠a a la reaparici√≥n de una econom√≠a de mercado y a una mayor competencia. Si hubiera sido de otra manera, la formaci√≥n de expectativas a largo plazo diferente de las expectativas a corto plazo habr√≠a sido sin sentido. Por lo tanto, la industria misma no consider√≥ que el desarrollo del sistema econ√≥mico nazi se dirig√≠a hacia la planificaci√≥n central y el socialismo. M√°s bien, el papel muy importante del Estado en la preguerra y en la econom√≠a de guerra se consideraba relacionada con la guerra- y por lo tanto temporal.‚ùû (Buchheim y Scherner, 2006, pp. 405).

En 1939, solamente la empresa privada IG Farben controlaba el 25% de los trabajadores de la industria qu√≠mica alemana, el 33% del capital nominal de ese sector, el 33% de la producci√≥n y el 66% de las exportaciones, sin tener en cuenta sus filiales extranjeras en Suiza y Suecia o sus contratos con la Standard Oil (Crouzet, 1961). Los beneficios empresariales de las empresas privadas como Krupp o IG Farben crecieron considerablemente durante el nazismo.

Las filiales alemanas de las empresas privadas General Motors y Ford Motor Company pose√≠an el 70% del mercado automovil√≠stico alem√°n en 1939 (Agosto, 2008), adem√°s de suministrar material b√©lico a la Wehrmacht durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial (Agosto, 2008). G√∂ring por su parte, dej√≥ que las empresas privadas financiar√≠an la industria de la aviaci√≥n para que la iniciativa privada se fortaleciera (Buchheim y Scherner, 2006). Es por ello, que no era raro que empresas privadas de la aviaci√≥n militar como Messerschmitt AG, Ernst Heinkel Flugzeugwerke AG o Junkers Flugzeug- und Motorenwerke AG fueran los principales proveedores de la Luftwaffe.

A diferencia de lo que se cree, la Alemania nazi no llev√≥ una pol√≠tica aut√°rquica, en cambio aumenta sus relaciones comerciales con distintos pa√≠ses como Bulgaria, Hungr√≠a, Grecia, Ruman√≠a, Yugoslavia o Turqu√≠a.

Tambi√©n esto ocurre en Latinoam√©rica. Entre 1932 y 1937 el volumen de las exportaciones alemanas a esa regi√≥n se cuadriplica y para 1936 Alemania se convierte en el principal proveedor de Chile y Brasil, as√≠ como el segundo de Per√∫, Bolivia, Venezuela, Guatemala y M√©xico (Crouzet, 1961).

La Alemania nazi aument√≥ sus relaciones comerciales con pr√°cticamente todos los pa√≠ses, salvo excepciones como la Uni√≥n Sovi√©tica, durante el periodo previo a la Segunda Guerra Mundial.

Por √∫ltimo, cabe destacar que los que realmente ganaron con la llegada de los nazis fueron los grandes capitalistas alemanes. Los salarios reales por hora de los trabajadores alemanes entre 1933 y 1939 crecieron solo alrededor de un 7,41% (Kirk, 1995), mientras que los salarios semanales reales crecieron cerca de un 20,11% (Kirk, 1995), esto fue el resultado del aumento de las horas de trabajo. Mientras tanto, el PIB per c√°pita en ese periodo creci√≥ un 54,53% (Maddison, 1997). El resto de crecimiento que no fue a parar a los salarios de los trabajadores fue, por defecto, al rendimiento del capital, que como se puede ver en esta gr√°fica del libro The Wages of Destruction: The Making and Breaking of the Nazi Economy (2006) de Adam Tooze (pp. 109), creci√≥ de forma espectacular durante el nazismo. Como resultado de esto, la desigualdad de ingresos r√°pidamente aument√≥ con los nazis. Entre 1933 y 1938, el 10% m√°s rico de Alemania pas√≥ de poseer el 11% de la renta nacional, a poseer el 16% (Atkinson y Piketty, 2007). Por su parte el 0,01% m√°s rico, entre ellos los grandes capitalistas, pasaron, en el mismo periodo, de poseer el 1,25% de la renta nacional a poseer el 2,5%, un aumento del 100% (Atkinson y Piketty, 2007). El aumento en la desigualdad fue debido a que el rendimiento del capital fue mayor al crecimiento econ√≥mico (r>g). Como se√±ala Piketty (2014):

‚ùùEs interesante se√±alar que la participaci√≥n del decil superior progres√≥ mucho en Alemania entre 1933 y 1938, totalmente a contracorriente de los dem√°s pa√≠ses: esta situaci√≥n refleja sobremanera el aumento de los beneficios industriales (estimulados por los pedidos gubernamentales a la industria de armamento) y, de manera m√°s general, el restablecimiento de las jerarqu√≠as de ingresos caracter√≠sticas del periodo nazi.‚ùû (pp. 357).

MajorLeague I really don't get what your point is or what are you trying to defend exactly, since you yourself admit that the Nazis were right-wing. You need to clarify your ideas before starting a discussion.

"The nazi Germany was not business friendly". Sure, tell Henry Ford, Hugo Boss or Ferdinand Porsche among others.

"The nazis were socialists like the name said". Most retard argument ever. By that logic North Korea is a democratic country.

"In other words, history, not me, calls nazis socialist". Maybe in your fantasy world. In real world the vast majority of historians agree that the Nazis were not socialists, and the few who claim that they were socialists are right-wingers who don't want to assume that their ideological "brothers" did some atrocities. Richard Evans, in his three-volume history of Nazi Germany, is quite clear on whether Hitler was a socialist: ‚ÄúIt would be wrong to see Nazism as a form of, or an outgrowth of, socialism.‚Äù Izidoro Blikstein, professor of Linguistics and Semiotics at USP and an expert in analysis of Nazi and totalitarian discourse, said: "Affirm that the Nazis were socialists is a great ignorance of history and how things happened"

"Can you give me an example of a marxist organization in German history which aligned with the term socialist as nazis did?". Didn't you read that famous interview with Hitler in which the first thing the journalist asks to him is: ""Why do you call yourself a National Socialist, since your party programme is the very antithesis of that commonly accredited to socialism?" and Hitler literally replied: "We might have called ourselves the Liberal Party. We chose to call ourselves the National Socialists". Yeah, it seems that the name of the party was really important to him and was carefully chosen to reflect his ideas......

"Are you sure you know what you're talking about?". I was thinking the same about you.

"From reading history and studying economics or from being pitched by socialist politicians?". So this is a conspiracy of socialist politicians to convince people about what exactly? that the Nazis were right-wing people who did some left-wing stuff? Ridiculous. Sorry to say but you're starting to sound like a lunatic. Look, the husband of a friend of mine is a neo-Nazi and I have talked a lot with him about this subject. I can assure you that he is not the typical retarded neo-Nazi who likes the Nazis "just because they were racist". He knows perfectly the "Nazi philosophy" and has read lots of books on the subject, and you know what? even he admits that the Nazis started being anti-capitalist and ended up being capitalist.

replies.text:
MajorLeague The Nazis were openly opposed in the Reichstag by the left wing Social Democrat and the moderate Center Party, and allied with the firmly right-wing militarists, blood and soil nutters, and the Freikorps. Even contemporary German newspapers described the Nazis as right-wing. In Volker Ullrich's Hitler biography he states that Hitler was always fundamentally far-right and that he adopted socialist language and some policy as a purely opportunistic move to attract working-class people to what was at the time called the German Worker's Party, but whose social base came from the middle classes.

What Hitler called "the real socialism" only existed in his head. Pretending that he was a socialist when he defended the opposite of socialism and even wanted to eradicate socialism, doesn't seem very socialist. If I now affirm that real socialism is capitalist and bourgeois, would you also buy the idea that I have "my own version of socialism" and that I am a socialist? sorry but that seems a bit naive.

You haven't answered my question why you think they were right-wing. I think you're starting to regret saying that.

Honestly, this conversation is starting to bore me A LOT. I feel like I'm talking to a wall. To end my participation and since you can read in spanish, I'm going to copy an article published in a Spanish right-wing newspaper called ABC, just to prove how absurd is the idea that only lefties say the Nazis were far-right:

AS√ç ALCANZARON LOS NAZIS EL PODER

En 1933 el Partido Nazi alcanza el poder. De ser una minoritaria ¬´banda de desarrapados y pistoleros¬ª, cuyos integrantes cab√≠an todos en una cervecer√≠a y limitaban su actuaci√≥n a Baviera, se ha convertido en uno de los fen√≥menos de masas m√°s importantes que se haya conocido. ¬øC√≥mo fue posible?

Tras el final de la Gran Guerra, son muchos los grup√∫sculos de extrema derecha activos en Alemania. Aun diferentes, todos comparten unas caracter√≠sti-cas comunes: el rechazo frontal al Tratado de Versallesy las condiciones de paz y la oposici√≥n radical a la democracia que encarna la Rep√∫blica de Weimar, a la que quieren derrocar y sustituir por un r√©gimen de corte autoritario. 

El Partido Obrero Alem√°n Nacional Socialista (NSDAP, en sus siglas, o Partido Nazi), fundado por Anton Drexler en enero de 1919, es uno m√°s de ellos. Ni el m√°s numeroso, ni el m√°s fuerte, ni el m√°s importante. Muy por delante en el ranking se encuentran dos organizaciones bien diferenciadas: los Stahlhelm o Cascos de Acero y el Partido Nacionalista del Pueblo Alem√°n o DNVP.

El ¬´Stahlhelm¬ª y el DNPV

Fundado por Franz Seldte como una ¬´organizaci√≥n social¬ª y apol√≠tica, el Stahlhelm se constituye como una entidad formada por veteranos de la Gran Guerra y ultranacionalistas, financiada por industriales y terratenientes alemanes, cuyo fin principal es la asistencia econ√≥mica a los excombatientes.

La realidad era harto diferente; el Stahlhelm se articula como una milicia paramilitar cuyo objetivo √∫ltimo es el derrocamiento de la Rep√∫blica, aunque, parad√≥jicamente, sirvi√≥ de reserva y apoyo al ej√©rcito de la misma: el Reichswher.

Alimentado por los integrantes de los disueltos ¬´Freikorps¬ª, el Stahlhelm fue durante la d√©cada de los a√±os veinte el m√°s poderoso de los grupos de la extrema derecha germanos y el preferido por Mussolini, que lo ve√≠a como su aliado natural en Alemania.

Sin embargo, con la llegada de Hitler al poder en 1933, el Stahlhelm es paulatinamente integrado ‚Äîno sin oposici√≥n‚Äî en la estructura del Partido Nazi y para 1934 hab√≠a desaparecido como entidad independiente.

Por su parte, el DNVP era el principal partido de la derecha nacionalista alemana, que hab√≠a obtenido un gran respaldo popular durante los primeros procesos electorales de la Rep√∫blica y, aunque integrado en el sistema, nunca acept√≥ realmente la legitimidad democr√°tica. Su postura se fue radicalizando al tiempo que perd√≠a apoyos populares.

Tanto su alianza ocasional con los nazis en el parlamento alem√°n como su radicalizaci√≥n tuvieron como consecuencia su gradual desaparici√≥n, siendo sus militantes y su masa electoral absorbida por el partido de Hitler, que, con un discurso intransigente, din√°mico y ¬´atractivo¬ª, cautivaba cada vez a m√°s sectores, no s√≥lo del electorado de la ultraderecha, sino de todas las capas de la sociedad.

El ascenso nazi

El giro de una gran parte de la derecha germana hacia posturas autoritarias y extremistas favorece el ascenso nacionalsocialista. El crecimiento del Partido Nazi bajo el liderazgo de Adolf Hitler desde 1921, es continuo.

Cautivador en su oratoria y puesta en escena, su ret√≥rica ultranacionalista, revisionista y antisemita le ganan el respaldo de una base social cada vez m√°s amplia y heterog√©nea: militantes de otros partidos de ultraderecha, pero tambi√©n empresarios, obreros, campesinos y clases medias.

El uso moderno de la propaganda y la violencia pol√≠tica son sus otras dos armas. Adem√°s, tras la fracasada experiencia del ¬´Putsch¬ª de M√∫nich, los dirigentes nazis est√°n convencidos de la necesidad de desbordar la Rep√∫blica desde dentro, participando y utilizando a su favor las instituciones republicanas. La aceptaci√≥n moment√°nea de las reglas democr√°ticas le dar√° adem√°s al partido el plus de respetabilidad del que hasta entonces carec√≠a.

El resentimiento por la ocupaci√≥n francesa del Ruhr y las sucesivas crisis econ√≥micas de 1923 y 1929 incrementan a√∫n m√°s la base electoral de Hitler: En las elecciones de 1932 los nazis, con un tercio de todos los votos, son el partido m√°s votado de Alemania. Con tal apoyo popular y el sustento de otras fuerzas del centro y la derecha, que piensan pueden ¬´domesticarlo¬ª una vez que cate las ¬´mieles del poder¬ª, Hitler es nombrado canciller por el presidente Hindenburg en enero de 1933.

replies.author: @santouchesantouche2873
replies.text:
MajorLeague ¬†your error is one of fact, not interpretation. Any analysis of the electoral platforms, internal party dynamics and political actions of the Nazis between 1921 and 1945 makes this clear. Perhaps the German Workers Party - the party of around 100 members led by Anton Drexler that preceded the Nazi Party (NSDAP) - might have sought to cobble authoritarian anti-capitalism (which is not the same as socialism) onto biological racism. The early, pre-Nazi party that Hitler joined toyed with forms of market control to benefit small businesses and to halt ostensible "foreign" - that is, Jewish - control over markets. But such dalliances would not last long. Yes, Mussolini had been a socialist early during the First World War, but broke with his comrades to support Italian expansionism, and then formed his fascist party to crush them. As in fascist Italy, Nazi ideas were self-consciously formulated to negate those of the left, not to imitate them. When Hitler took over the party in 1921, he shredded the anti-capitalist parts of the old party's platform.This was a politics forged in the late days of the German revolution, when Hitler began to imagine Germany assailed by a double threat of Jews and Bolsheviks emanating from the Russian east: "Judeo-Bolshevism." This position would undergird the foreign policy aspects of Mein Kampf. Far from supporting anti-colonial movements at the time, as did socialists around the world, he admired the British Empire as a paragon of "Aryan" rule over inferiors, and hoped to cooperate with the British in rescuing Western civilization from Soviet "Asiatic" barbarism.Under Hitler the party looked squarely to the middle classes and farmers rather than the working class for a political base. Hitler realigned it to ensure that it was an anti-socialist, anti-liberal, authoritarian, pro-business party - particularly after the failed Beerhall Putsch of 1923. The "socialism" in the name National Socialism was a strategically chosen misnomer designed to attract working class votes where possible, but they refused to take the bait. The vast majority voted for the Communist or Social Democratic parties.The minority anti-capitalist strand of Nazism (Strasserism) on which fastens was eliminated well before 1934, when Gregor Strasser and the Storm Trooper (SA) leader Ernst Roehm were murdered with over eighty others in the "Night of the Long Knives." In fact, Strasserism had already been defeated at the Bamberg Conference of 1926 when the Nazis were polling under 3% of the vote. Here, Hitler brought the dissidents back into line, denouncing them as "communists" and ruling out land expropriations and grassroots decision-making. He heightened the party's alliance with businesses small and large, and insisted on the absolute centralisation of decision-making - the "Fuehrer (leader) Principle."
When the already isolated Strasser brothers tried to reinvigorate their project one last time in 1930, Hitler and Goebbels banded together to force Otto Strasser to leave the party and Gregor Strasser to publicly recant. When the first electoral breakthrough to a popular vote of 18% came in 1930, the Nazi party's anti-capitalist minority were well and truly defeated. The "Night of the Long Knives" purged the old SA, not because they were a hidden vestige of socialism, but because Roehm's army of street thugs were a potential threat to Hitler's personal consolidation of power. A struggle over socialism in the Nazi party played absolutely no role in the purge of 1934.For their part, businesses welcomed the Nazis' promises to suppress the left. On 20 February 1933, Hitler and Goering met with a large group of industrialists when Hitler declared that democracy and business were incompatible and that the workers needed to be dragged away from socialism. He promised bold action to protect their businesses and property from communism. The industrialists - including leading figures from I.G. Farben, Hoesch, Krupp, Siemens, Allianz and other senior mining and manufacturing groups - then contributed more than two million Reichsmarks

replies.author: @santouchesantouche2873
replies.text:
MajorLeague also a form of socialism/fascism, one wonders?)Herewith we come to the effect, if not the point, of the revisionist exposition: it is not only to transfer the stigma of the Second World War's genocidal violence from the right to the left, so that criticisms of racialized populism can be dismissed as "leftist fascism." It is also to suggest that the war was a crusade against state collectivism of all types - including the welfare state for which many Westerners, in fact, fought. They reason by means of a simplistic, ahistorical syllogism: since socialism is statism/collectivism (like public health and public transport), and Nazism was statist/collectivist (and promoted public health and public transport), social democratic public health and public transport measures must be fascist.The war against welfare states
Needless to say, this is a perverse and pernicious misinterpretation of historical facts. The Atlantic Charter, declared by U.S. President Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Churchill in 1941, set out the principles of the post-war order, which included the "advancement of social welfare" and working "for a world free of want and fear." A year later, the British Beveridge Report on social welfare met such popular support that a reluctant cabinet felt compelled to accept it. When the war ended, the people promptly replaced Churchill's government with a Labour one to implement its recommendations.Three years later, the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights, inspired by the Atlantic Charter, reflected the Zeitgeist in Article 25: "Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and wellbeing of himself and his family including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood." Welfare states were thus established or extended after the war. They have now been under concerted attack since the 1970s. Governments across the Western world are still deregulating, imposing austerity and attacking unions to further increase business profit margins. The emergence of leaders like Trump around the globe signals an intensification of this tendency.Worried by the popularity among young people of politicians like Jeremy Corbyn and Bernie Sanders who oppose these tendencies, however, the corporate and media sponsors of the attacks on the welfare state now seek to discredit the social democratic platform by disparaging it as historically fascist. That is also why they attack reputable sources of news like the ABC, and why they seek at once to discredit universities as "politically correct" and to pervert their mission by inserting into them privatised think thanks espousing Hayakian ideology. So, too, they proffer the perverse thesis of fascism-as-socialism, finding ready adherents in right-wing corners of the twittersphere and in business circles.The collective ignorance displayed by this revisionist commentariat is proportionally related to the outlandishness of its historical interpretations and its sophomoric ignorance of the recent history of Western civilization.The revisionists likely neither know nor care that the monument erected to the German strikers who lost their lives confronting the Kapp Putsch was ritually destroyed by the Nazis in 1936. But others do. Whether those who remember the past can confront the slow-motion putsch against welfare states and the historical experiences of the catastrophic twentieth century that spawned them remains an open question.

replies.author: @SaraSwank
replies.text:
MajorLeague I'm going to post one more thing because I think this is interesting. This is about Gregor Strasser and it‚Äôs on his German wikipedia file:

"Despite his reputation as a representative of the left within the NSDAP, Strasser had had good contacts with entrepreneurial circles since the beginning of the thirties, whose ideas of taming the NSDAP by integrating him into government responsibility met him. The German Fuehrer Letters, a private correspondence under the influence of the industrialist Paul Silverberg, praised Strasser in May 1932 because he advocated a "transfer of the N.S.D.A.P. from the opposition to the governmental position ". To prove his party's ability to govern, Strasser announced on October 20, 1932 in the Berlin Sports Palace the new "economic reconstruction program" of the NSDAP. In it, the shrill anti-capitalist tones and the demands for a self-sufficiency of Germany were clearly withdrawn, as they had been among others in his own "economic emergency program" of July 1932 still loud. Instead of tax increases for the rich, he now demanded tax cuts, and instead of price controls, he wanted to fight deflation with a price liberalization. Although he continued to speak in favor of agricultural protectionism and priority for German products, he emphasized at the same time that exports should not be hindered. To overcome mass unemployment, he proposed abandoning the Reichsmark's bond with gold, nationalizing the banks and facilitating public employment through massive government borrowing. In the same year he expressed himself in an interview with the American journalist Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker *extremely business-friendly* :

"We recognize private property. We accept the private initiative. We recognize our debt and our commitment to pay for it. We are against the nationalization of the industry. We are against the nationalization of trade. We are against the planned economy in the Soviet sense."

Also Gottfried Feder in his _Manifesto for the abolition of interest slavery_ was hard against the socialization of the means of production:

"The essential demand of the Erfurt Program (the transfer of the means of production from private ownership into the ownership and operation of the community) has today been compressed into the cry for "socialization." It is completely clear to every serious politician that full socialization of our economic ruin would mean complete state bankruptcy. But one dare not confess this openly and freely to the people. replies.author: @ManiacMayhem7256
replies.text:
@teutonicterror0322 
¬†@Teutonicterror 03¬† 
¬†@Teutonicterror 03¬† 
"How is it socialist?" I myself never said it was. TIK and I disagree on that, but agree on this: The NSDAP economy was left wing. In terms of economic policies, it leans pretty well into the left, right of Stalin and Lenin but left of Roosevelt. Furthermore you're making a false equivalency. Other states regulate, but to a far lesser degree and for very different reasons than why the TR did it. You're looking at similarities without seeing context or scope or frequency, a failing Hayes excellently called out Buchheim on. My main thing on the NSDAP economy is that the left is more incorrect than the right on this subject and is relying on outdated Soviet historiography. The capitalism in decay model. Primacy of economics. Seeing The Vampire Economy and many primary and secondary sources, it was constantly remarked on how regulated the economy of the TR was. Why would people be commenting on this if it was just standard for all economies? It's because the scope, context and frequency was drastically different. The economy of the TR is most similar to that of China, a country that many far leftists even today praise. Tankies. Peer reviewed case studies have been done on the room for maneuver in the TR, and these historians found Peter Hayes had a far better case than Buchheim. I can link. Historians have compared and contrasted the economies of the TR and other contemporary western countries, and found other western countries were far less centralized and more willing to let private enterprise have far more autonomy than that of the TR. You're being disingenuous for the sake of ideology, something you're accusing TIK of. You think economic regulation, Socialism and leftism are good, therefore the evil TR must not be associated with these today or it looks bad. And I'm saying this as a guy who's a social corporatist. 
The NSDAP by the mid 20s had a clear economic ideology. It was in the program and Rainer Zeitelmann more than demonstrated it in his book. These programs weren't enacted not out of ideological inconsistency, but out of pragmatism. The NSDAP, as Evans says, needed money. So they couldn't nationalize the banks. But he himself says they subjected banks to heavy regulation. Regulation was part of NSDAP ideology. Several H quotes prove this as does the program. As time went on, as Rainer proves, H got more admiring of the USSR overtime and admired their planned economy.  
You're framing it in too easy a light. The article makes clear while some room for maneuver was maintained, outside the firms all control no longer existed, far less than that of the Weimar days. Weimar wasn't a laissez Faire paradise either. Furthermore you intentionally ignore nationalization done by the NSDAP.

replies.author: @ManiacMayhem7256
replies.text:
@teutonicterror0322 
Final conclusion: I used to be like you. I used to take leftist ideas about the NSDAP from the internet and held it as true. I was a leftist and to this day I still hold many leftist ideas unlike TIK, and I butchered Wikipedia articles (the vandalism remains to this day) and wasted all that time on what was truly nonsense. I was doing it out of insecurity in my ideology, I was angry and scared when people compared leftism and National Socialism. It made me feel insecure. And i hyper obsessed with with Socialism part. The same arguments you're using now I used before, I even used the sources one against TIK without ever having read the sources. They were written by right wing men therefore they're bad. But I never retorted the substance. It was during this time i had a deep feeling my ideas on National Socialism made zero sense. Then it all shattered when I read Richard Evans trilogy. That book completely changed my view on it. The left had it completely wrong. The right isn't even 65 percent correct but they were more correct on this particular topic than the right. The totalitarianism model and capitalism in decay model are both heavily outdated, but the former was better than the latter, as Timothy Mason showed. Now we have more nuanced views, Hayes being the best, and that's the view I share today.

replies.author: @ManiacMayhem7256
replies.text:
@teutonicterror0322 
As for your first comment, it's mainly restating things so my comment will be brief in response 
Can't really respond to first paragraph since we're coming at this on so different a side that we aren't going to agree on it at all and can't be proved one way or the other, so I'll leave that. Will say however even if you don't count centralization, nationalization or regulation as left wing, their large welfare state and mass programs certainly were. Even the corporate tax rate was tied to it and by the mid 40s was 60 percent. Taxes I actually think in themselves aren't in the spectrum but when used for quasi redistribution I think it's fair to say. 
They nationalized Catholic schools largely due to their opposition to Catholicism and their competition with the HY. As for saying they privatized a lot more, I am not sure. There hasn't been a case study done on this yet. 500 companies nationalized is a lot after all. These weren't J companies btw they were domestic and foreign ones mainly relating to the iron and steel industries. Forgot to note about privatization, many companies sold off were sold off to NSDAP organization, thus in effect still remaining in the control of the state, if in name having a quasi private owner.   
Not much to say on the regulation part. It's a restating of points so I'll leave that be.
H did have an economic ideology and evidence shows the economy while not of primary importance certainly was of a large tertiary importance behind war and race. It was inherently tied to the very important idea of Labensraum. The idea came from an economist after all. H has several quotes where he says the NSDAP does have an economic ideology, and even quotes the program saying so. What he says it is in 1927, is exactly how the economy worked form 33 to 45. Zeitelmann has numerous examples on this. Strasser was a member of the party but Otto was expelled by 30 and was never very influential in his economic ideology. Gregor, much more in line with H, even supported the expulsion though he met his maker in 34. The economic ideas of the NSDAP were a rough outline when compared to other parties, but an outline nonetheless. I highly recommend Zeitelmanns book btw. He maybe right wing now, but by his own admission in the revised book he was left wing when he wrote it. I also recommend Gellately and Aly. You can of course balance it with Tooze's response to Aly. I highly recommend Evans book on historiography. It even mentions the debate. 
Social corporatism is a non coercive non fascist version of corporatism that pre dates fascism. China is definitely the closest example of a fascist economy, followed closely by Russia.

Never said more left wing. Quote where I said that. Economically sure but I stated NSDAP was overall far right. The far right constantly borrow from the social democratic left especially in economics. 
I said in terms of how the economy worked. It was in between Roosevelt's Keynesian market economy America and Stalin's planned economy USSR. Read. 
Socialism can be state or worker control. Ever heard of state Socialism? Also clearly you didn't read because I said NSDAP wasn't  socialist. They weren't capitalist either. I precisely said they were corporatist, third positionist. Capitalism is private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit. Socialism is public ownership of the means of production. The NSDAP represented a third position to this as did Italy. The means of production were privately owned, but controlled by the state and the profit motive subordinated in favor of the state's interests. This was evident by the time of the four year plan which, according to Richard Evans, heavily cut into the profits of many companies when they began to chafe under demands, subordination of the operation of the means of production for profit for the goals of the state, in this case being gearing for war and establishing totalitarian rule. Italy had the second highest rate of state owned industry by the 1930s.
The NSDAP wasn't very supportive of free enterprise. They only did such if it was seen as beneficial. If your private company was seen as being more efficient if it was ran by the state, then it would be nationalized or your entire board kicked out for more favorable NSDAP friendly people or disadvantaged by the state who would give the contract to your competitor as punishment. See Junkers, Thyssen, 500 companies nationalized by Gor, and many other examples I listed. In a totalitarian state, both private and public property are instruments for the state to use. You can own a private business, but more or less it is controlled by the state, as Germa Bel noted in against the mainstream. H also became an admirer of USSR's planned economy according to Rainer Zeitelmann which he demonstrates in his book. Had NSDAP won the war, likely they would have emulated it given the chance. 
The left and right are wrong on this. Hearing both of these sides discuss this is like hearing Peterson discuss Marxism. The second hand cringe is palpable. There's a reason academia doesn't take Eco or Parenti's works on this subject seriously.

replies.author: @Counter-Intuitive
replies.text:
In the months after Hitler took power, SA and Gestapo agents went from door to door looking for Hitler‚Äôs enemies. They arrested Socialists, Communists, trade union leaders, and others who had spoken out against the Nazi party; some were murdered. By the summer of 1933, the Nazi party was the only legal political party in Germany. Nearly all organized opposition to the regime had been eliminated. Democracy was dead in Germany.
However, the assumption that because the word ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù appeared in the party‚Äôs name and socialist words and ideas popped up in the writings and speeches of top Nazis then the Nazis must have been actual socialists is naive and ahistorical. What the evidence shows, on the contrary, is that Nazi Party leaders paid mere lip service to socialist ideals on the way to achieving their one true goal: raw, right-wing totalitarian power.

Yes, the Nazis were indisputably Right-Wing

Sometimes the claim is bandied about that the Nazis were a left-wing party on economic questions, perhaps because the Nazis were called ‚ÄúNational socialists‚Äù. This is flatly and completely wrong and a form of pseudo-historiography. Here‚Äôs why:

The Nazi party was built on right-wing voters and a right-wing support base:

There are many disputes about the nature of Hitler‚Äôs voting base. What isn‚Äôt under dispute though is that prior to voting Nazi, Nazi voters voted for centre-right and far-right parties, or didn‚Äôt vote at all. Support for the Nazis¬†did not¬†come from disaffected left-wing or centre-left voters, but from right-wing voters frustrated with the existing parties of the right.

In my view this point alone is decisive. The meaning of right-wing and left-wing is not an ahistorical abstraction, it‚Äôs created by the behaviour of people and institutions. The right-wing citizens of Germany implicitly recognised the Nazis as right-wing by voting for them, case closed.

Read more about which parties Nazi voters defected from here:¬†https://gking.harvard.edu/files/gking/files/nazivp.pdf

2. The Nazis literally invented privatisation:

The Nazis were responsible for huge privatisation programs. The extent of their privatisations was enormous, but it was particularly vast when compared with other countries at the time, who were generally moving in the opposite direction. The privatisations of Nazi Germany may indeed have been the first mass privatisations of public property in history and included ‚ÄúSteel, mining, banking, shipyard, ship-lines, and railways.‚Äù More on how Nazis bucked historical trends by privatising when no one else was here:¬†http://www.ub.edu/graap/nazi.pdf

3. Nazi policies greatly increased income inequality:

Income inequality spiked under Hitler, as was observed even at the time. More here:¬†http://piketty.pse.ens.fr/files/capitalisback/CountryData/Germany/Other/Pre1950Series/RefsHistoricalGermanAccounts/Sweezy39.pdf

4. Capital as a share of factor income also spiked under Hitler, at the expense of wages:

Factor income describes the division between the factors of production, with land receiving rent, capital receiving profit and labour receiving wages. The capital share, or profit as a proportion of total income, increased by about 50% in Nazi Germany and was much higher than the US‚Äôs capital share at the time. See the below graph from¬†Capital in the Twenty-First Century¬†reproduced in a Jacobin article by Corey Robin:
I‚Äôm sorry if there‚Äôs not much in the way of Belles-lettres here. If I am blunt it is for a purpose. The Nazis were right-wing. Anyone who tells you otherwise is wrong, much in the same way it is wrong to say that the world is flat, six-thousand years old, or made of cheese.

replies.author: @blixer8384
replies.text:
MajorLeague First and foremost not everything that attacks the character of the source is an ad Hominem attack. An ad Hominem attack is a fallacy of relevance meaning that it would only be an ad Hominem if the attack upon the sources character is not a relevant reason as to why they're wrong. Saying someone is a liar as a reason not to trust their word is an attack upon the individuals character but it whether or not someone is truthful is very relevant to whether or not they should be trusted. Likewise arguing that someone should not be trusted because they help make videos for a YouTube channel that generally speaking does not produce trustworthy information in it's videos is very relevant to whether or not they can be trusted as a source of trustworthy information
Secondly even if it was a fallacy arguing that because the argument is illogical it's claims must be untruthful is in and of itself a fallacy of relevance. Because the logicality of an argument tells us nothing of the truthfulness of it's claims. The only time one tells us the other is when an argument has true premises and false conclusions. Such an argument is inherently illogical. Specifically it is the formal fallacy of "Drawing a Negative Conclusion from Affirmative Premises" ... Yes that is literally the name of the fallacy. 
Finally PragerU is objectively propaganda. Everything it says is either a misrepresentation of the facts or simply an ought right lie to support the ideological beliefs of it's founder. It does not even attempt to hdie the fact that it is a partisan organization led by a hyper partisan bastard who thinks anyone to the left of McCarthy needs to be destroyed.

replies.author: @TheHaighus
replies.text:
michael parkinson 
Politics are better viewed on two axes than one. If you look at left and right as separate to authoritarianism vs liberalism, you get a more accurate picture of philosophical ideology. Anarchism is the extreme end of liberalising policy, but can be both right and left wing- anarchosocialism and anarchocapitalism respectively. Neither of these are supposed to have rulers. Anarchism as a term is generally more associated with the left today, with anarchocapitalists usually identifying as libertarian instead.

However, not all right wing thought is liberal and anarchistic. Absolute monarchists are right wing, and fall onto the authoritarian end of the spectrum.

The use of a phrase several thousand years ago isn't terribly relevant to how the phrases have been used over recent centuries, language evolves to suit the needs of those using it.

replies.text: Socialism is the science of dealing with the common weal. Communism is not Socialism. Marxism is not Socialism. The Marxians have stolen the term and confused its meaning. I shall take Socialism away from the Socialists. Socialism is an ancient Aryan, Germanic institution. Our German ancestors held certain lands in common. They cultivated the idea of the common weal. Marxism has no right to disguise itself as socialism. Socialism, unlike Marxism, does not repudiate private property. replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd
replies.text: To put it quite clearly: we have an economic program. Point 13 in that program demands the nationalization of all public companies, in other words socialization, or what is known here as socialism. ‚Ä¶ the good of the community takes priority over that of the individual. But the State should retain control; every owner should feel himself to be an agent of the State; it is his duty not to misuse his possessions to the detriment of the State or the interests of his fellow countrymen. That is the overriding point. The Third Reich will always retain the right to control property owners. If you say that the bourgeoisie is tearing its hair over the question of private property, that does not affect me in the least. Does the bourgeoisie expect some consideration from me? Today‚Äôs bourgeoisie is rotten to the core; it has no ideals anymore; all it wants to do is earn money and so it does me what damage it can. The bourgeois press does me damage too and would like to consign me and my movement to the devil.‚Äù ‚Äì May 4, 1931, interview with Richard Breiting

replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd

replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd

They hate this Germany which in the course of seven years has labored to afford its Volksgenossen a decent life. They hate this Germany which has eliminated unemployment, which, in spite of all their wealth, they have not been able to eliminate. This Germany which grants its laborers decent housing‚Äîthis is what they hate because they have a feeling their own peoples could be ‚Äòinfected‚Äô thereby. replies.text: The hammer will once more become the symbol of the German worker and the sickle the sign of the German peasant.‚Äù ‚Äì May 1, 1934, May Day speech in Berlin

replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd
replies.text: Is there a nobler or more excellent kind of Socialism and is there a truer form of Democracy than this National Socialism which is so organized that through it each one among the millions of German boys is given the possibility of finding his way to the highest office in the nation, should it please Providence to come to his aid?‚Äù ‚Äì January 30, 1937, On National Socialism and World Relations speech in the German Reichstag

replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd
replies.text: And justice is on the side of those nations that fight for their threatened existence. And this struggle for existence will spur these nations on to the most tremendous accomplishments in world history. If profit is the driving force for production in the democracies‚Äîa profit that industrialists, bankers, and corrupt politicians pocket‚Äîthen the driving force in National Socialist Germany and Fascist Italy is the realization by millions of laborers that, in this war, it is they who are being fought against. They realize that the democracies, if they should ever win, would rage with the full capitalist cruelty, that cruelty of which only those are capable whose only god is gold, who know no human sentiments other than their obsession with profit, and who are ready to sacrifice all noble thought to this profit instinct without hesitation. This struggle is not an attack on the rights of other nations, but on the arrogance and avarice of a narrow capitalist upper class, one which refuses to acknowledge that the days are over when gold ruled the world, and that, by contrast, a future is dawning when the people will be the determining force in the life of a nation.‚Äù ‚Äì January 1, 1941, speech in Berlin

replies.author: @Jimmy-sz5wd
replies.text: In those countries, it is actually capital that rules; that is, nothing more than a clique of a few hundred men who possess untold wealth and, as a consequence of the peculiar structure of their national life, are more or less independent and free. They say: ‚ÄòHere we have liberty.‚Äô By this they mean, above all, an uncontrolled economy, and by an uncontrolled economy, the freedom not only to acquire capital but to make absolutely free use of it. That means freedom from national control or control by the people both in the acquisition of capital and in its employment. This is really what they mean when they speak of liberty. These capitalists create their own press and then speak of the ‚Äòfreedom of the press.‚Äô In reality, every one of the newspapers has a master, and in every case this master is the capitalist, the owner. This master, not the editor, is the one who directs the policy of the paper. If the editor tries to write other than what suits the master, he is ousted the next day. This press, which is the absolutely submissive and characterless slave of the owners, molds public opinion. Yes, certainly, we jeopardize the liberty to profiteer at the expense of the community, and, if necessary, we even abolish it.‚Äù ‚Äì December 10, 1940, speech in Berlin

author: @ashevillecat
text:
To sum it up in a few sentences: The Nazis added the word "socialist" to their party's name - against Hitler's objections - to appeal to the left leaning working class in order to draw them away from Communism and toward volkish nationalism. The Nazi version of socialism relied on redefining German society from the notion of "Reichsdeutsche" (citizens of the German Empire) to that of "Volksdeutsche" (Germans with regard to ethnicity or race, rather than citizenship). Drexler specified that the socialist platform was only meant to give social welfare to German citizens deemed part of the Aryan race. 



So no, Hitler and the NSDAP were NOT socialist in any sense it was or is used otherwise. It was no more socialist than the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is democratic.

replies.author: @Jefffrrry
replies.text:
PauliBhoy is correct, there was no socialism in Nazi Germany.

Socialism first and foremost is a system where the workers own the means of production and they themselves manage the enterprises. That has never happened under the Nazis, Hitler detested that with a passion. There was wide support for social policies, sure, but better access to healthcare, higher pensions, etc. is not socialism.

Hitler toned down the anti-socialist / anti-communist rhetoric for a while when he courted the USSR so they could divide Europe between them easily. That was not an ideological pact tho, it was a pact between two countries that both felt screwed over by the rest. And even when the state took control of the whole economy in order to throw everything into the total war, they didn't do it because of socialism, they just had to. And the workers saw nothing from it.

replies.author: @ManiacMayhem7256
replies.text:
Not quite true. For one, Hitler definitely considered himself a socialist. It's all over his second book and his private conversations with Otto Wagener and the Table Talks. He didn't object to the party being called socialist until way later, preferring social revolutionary, which to him meant the exact same thing. He didn't define socialism as nationalism but as collectivism and communitarianism
"If we are socialists, then we must oppose materialism and mammonism, how as a socialist can you not be an anti se*ite?"
"From the right we take from the bourgois tradition, nationalism. From the Marxist tradition we take vital, creative socialism" both are quotes from Hitler. It's laid out in the 25 point programme with "Common good before the individual good" they didn't put socialism in their name to trick workers, they truly believed themselves to be socialists. 
North Korea has the state controlling the entire economy, which is defined as state socialism and fits with what Marx wrote and before Marx, Babeuf, the founder of modern socialism. 
Hitler himself had extreme state control over the economy albeit not disregarding private ownership entirely (though private property rights were gone by 1933). However later on late into the war he admired Stalin's planned economy and said to Speer he wished he could've nationalized all corporations and their unearned profits. 
All quotes come from Wikiquote and are backed by sources. 
Recommended reading, Hitler's True Believers by Robert Gellately and Hitler's National Socialism by Rainer Zeitelmann

You're distorting the facts for your own agenda
Hitler did "privatize" industries, however here's a huge caveat mentioned by the paper itself. For one, all of those industries were sold off to party members and party organizations, which were part of the state. Therefore all they did, according to the paper, wasn't liberalizing the economy, it was "privatization to make funds while still increasing state control over the economy and private enterprise." In the paper its mentioned state control and regulations aided this goal. According to it "While business did maintain some room for maneuver inside firms, due to state control, they had lost all control outside the firm and in the market." As Orwell put it "Everyone was a state employee, albeit the salaries varied greatly." Peter Temin remarks this is very similar to Lenin's economy under the NEP. 
Hitler nationalized labor unions and Catholic schools into the DAF and Hitler Youth. He nationalized privately owned unions into a state owned one. 
Lenin and Stalin persecuted Menshiviks, anarchists, and the latter Trotskyists. Lenin also persecuted peasants and Krondstadt sailors. Were they not socialists? 
Big business and monarchists didnt help the NSDAP until 1933, as Richard Evans notes, and clearly it backfired. Most of the monarchists were wiped out in the Night of the Long Knives and the DNVP banned, the big businessmen became controlled by the state by the time of the four year plan. Thyssen had became disillusioned and Krupp stepped down because of it. Richard Evans talks about it. It's like you people never read a book.
