Socialism is derived from Babeuf. In his philosophy we can find what socialism means. According to Rothbard: "In the ideal¬†communist society¬†sought by the Conspiracy, private property would be abolished, and all property would be communal and stored in communal storehouses. From these storehouses, the goods would be distributed ‚Äúequitably‚Äù by the superiors‚Äîapparently, there was to be a cadre of ‚Äúsuperiors‚Äù in this oh so ‚Äúequal‚Äù world!" Most scholars define socialism as public ownership of the means of production. Public can mean worker or state. There's state socialism, syndicalism and guild socialism for example. The philosophy of Italian Fascism didn't differ much from the last one. For the NSDAP, the means of production were privately owned, but only nominally. Property could be seized by the state at any time, all companies were forcibly cartelized into 13 corporations and regulations and restrictions were strict. In effect, this was de facto state control over the means of production. Perhaps not ownership, but definitely control. Capitalism is the private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit. While technically the means of production was privately owned in Nazi Germany, the profit motive was eliminated, focused entirely on rearmament no matter if it reduced profits or even hurt them. Perhaps then the Nazi system lays in between this. Between socialism and capitalism. Perhaps corporatism best describes it, an inherently collectivist economic philosophy with roots in syndicalism. 
The Nazis didn't detest socialism. They wouldn't have considered themselves socialists if they did. Class revolution isn't always a feature of socialism. There are many non revolutionary forms of socialism. Revolution was mainly from Marx and Babeuf. Many socialists during that time were utopians who didn't want struggle. Hitler himself considered himself a revolutionary, and Zeitelmann and I agree. He represents a form of right wing revolution that overthrew the Weimar Republic. Hitler replaced class warfare with r*cial warfare, borrowing from Marx. Instead of all history being class struggle, it was racial struggle. This is almost like a racial Marxism if you will. Instead of everything being viewed with class lenses, it was race lenses, but the logic and points remained the same. Hitler even said this in MK, saying "Without race, we would simply be competing with Marxism on their own ground" 
The idea of peoples community was the idea that all class barriers (not classes themselves, but barriers) would be removed and it would be a total meritocracy. This is read in the 25 point program as common law replaces Roman law. The Nazis even made all Germans legally the same, removing aristocratic and capitalist legal protections. Obviously this didn't extend to people they were racist towards. But within, with welfare and changes in law, people could move up without barriers and overall society would be equal in a way. The gap between rich and poor lessened considerably. This was prevalent in the military, where the lowest worker could rise up to become a general, free of old aristocratic military tradition. Hitler himself was homeless at one point. Not defending the Nazis btw, just showing their ideology.
Planned economy is different from command. China and Third Reich are command, USSR was planned. State capitalism doesn't mean if firms are private or public, only of the state operates the economy is a market way

For easy example take Bernie Sanders, many wrongly call him socialist, he described himself as democratic socialist, yet in reality his proposed policies more closely resemble social democratic ones. What seems like small nuances are actually huge differencies. Did Hitler employ socialistic policies? Yes, absolutely. But the most important aspect of socialism is missing here and was never even attempted by the Nazis.

I mean, if we count USSR as a form of state capitalism, with 5 year plans, whole industries nationalized and state owned, running a market with next to no competition, closed off, heavily regulated, warped and artificially ran... then Nazi Germany and China fall under it too and actually fulfill the name and definition more faithfully.

As was pointed by others above, Fascism and Nazism don't really operate on the capitalist vs. socialist division, their goal was to end both systems, which they saw as having developed in the wrong direction, and replace it with their third way. Nazism then added onto it in-built aryan superiority and anti-semitism, in a nutshell. Logically they would use policies employed by both and end up at a point between them, and logically one side's policies would be employed more. That's given by default. And you will be described by one of the derived labels. But unless you go all the way, and actually seize the means of productions, your system is not in reality socialism, no matter how you yourself name it. Just like the Great October Socialist Revolution wasn't really great, didn't really happen in october (yeah, yeah, different calendar) and wasn't very socialist. Naming something one way doesn't simply make it so.

I really don't know how to describe it in another words anymore. These are thus my closing words. Hitler was not a socialist, because he simply didn't employ and didn't even want to employ socialism. 11 That all unearned income, and all income that does not arise from work, be abolished.

He is for the only freedom that can be a serious fact, namely for the freedom of the state and the freedom of the individual in the state. And this is because for the fascist everything in the state and Nothing is human or spiritual and does not even have value outside the state. In this sense, fascism is totalitarian and the fascist state, as a synthesis and unity of all values, interprets and develops the entire people's life, and also enhances its rhythm".

Signs of totalitarianism for Mussolini:

- State management is strictly from the top down, from the leader to the smallest cogs.

- The definition of the state of a person's place in society and its tasks.

- Denial of classes, social groups and any other forms of an association of citizens. There is only a state and an individual.

- Everyone is valued exactly as much as he fully corresponds to his place in the state machinery.

- Identification and control by the state of absolutely all aspects of the individual's life (for example, the citizens' selection programs in the Reich).

These signs are important, but in general they are not limited to totalitarianism. This is a whole ideology.

But after the war, Zbigniew Brzezinski came up with his definition of totalitarianism:

- The only mass party headed by a charismatic leader and absorbing a relatively small part of the population (up to 10%), whose core is unshakably committed to ideology. The party is organized according to the oligarchic principle and, as a rule, either stands above the bureaucratic state organization, or is completely intertwined with it;

- An official ideology covering all vital aspects of human existence and which should be recognized by all;

- Centralized system of control and management of the economy.

- Monopoly on the media;

- Monopoly on all means of armed struggle;

- A system of terrorist police control directed not only against the "enemies" of the regime, but also against arbitrarily chosen groups and classes of the population;

This, in contrast to the concept of Mussolini - just a set of signs. Moreover, Brzezinski himself set them up according to the principle of the greatest conformity to their American notions of the USSR.

The option of Brzezinski will not be considered, for this is just his invention for equating the USSR to fascism.

A version of Mussolini for the USSR of the times of Stalin is not suitable, because the role of councils and collectivism was great at this time. And the state was considered only as a temporary higher form of the collective (until the victory of the world revolution).

replies.author: @Mentol_
replies.text:
"Of course the Soviet Union had finance capital" - financial capital is banking + industrial. The purpose of capital is to increase it, and Soviet money is used as a means of exchange for goods. Thus, the Soviet economy does not use money as a means to create capital until 1965 when the Kosygin reforms were used.

"When the decision was made in Moscow to open a copper mine in Mongolia, they obviously used finance capital to do so" - This is true only within the framework of the capitalist system. In the USSR there was socialism and therefore, to begin any major project, you did not need money. The main thing is to have resources and workers. The more goods will be produced - the more money they will be provided. 

"Soviet Union didn't have chauvinism? Explain the Great Patriotic War and its Great Russian slant" - What does the great Russian bias mean? According to statistics, ethnic Russian soldiers made up about 65% of the total number of Soviet soldiers. The rest were other nationalities. Yes, Soviet officers preferred to use Slavs at the front instead of others, but this is not connected with chauvinism policy, but with military pragmatism - Slavs had better motivation to fight and better education. For example, the peoples of the Caucasus had problems with motivation (therefore, some of them were later deported for cooperation with the Nazis), and people from Central Asia had a poor level of education and some of them did not even know Russian. Thus it is impossible to use such people in the Soviet army. 

"Or the ethnic cleansing of the Western Muslims from 1944 to the Khrushchev era" - what does mean? Crimean Tatars and Chechens? They were deported for collaboration with the Nazis in large quantities. Some nationalities (for example, the Volga Germans and Koreans in the Far East) were preventively deported. 

"As for Dimitrov, do some research on the looting of capital and industry of Bulgaria by the Soviet Union" - I don't know, maybe it was part of the war reparations. Bulgaria has traditionally been an agrarian state and did not have a strong industry. 

"Enver Hoxha later on termed it Soviet social-imperialism" - imperialism means that the USSR creates privileges for itself. Can you name some?

"National Socialism and the Marxist regimes should be called fascist if we actually mean totalitarian" - as I showed in the previous report, the term totalitarianism was interpreted after the war to unite the USSR and Germany as a common enemy for the West. What is important for us is that the Soviet government did not consider itself fascist, and the Nazis denied Marxism and the class struggle.

"I think the annihilation of liberal democracy, civil society, checks and balances, unlimited terror from the police and unitary dictatorship apply to all those regimes, with varying degrees" - if you have a red apple and a tomato, then you see that they are both red, both are round and both can be eaten. But this does not mean that they are the same. To check this you need to look at the foundation of this phenomenon. 

"Soviet's under Lenin and Trotsky and the Chekists was the worst regime ever" - It is documented that during Lenin, Soviet democracy was not destroyed. For example, in January 1918, Lenin wanted to make peace with Germany immediately, but the Soviet government did not support him in the framework of a vote - it supported Trotsky‚Äôs point of view "neither peace nor war" and therefore the war was continued. 

"Satanic hell" - demonization is part of propaganda.

replies.author: @kylehill6384
replies.text:
@Mentol_ "This is true only within the framework of the capitalist system. In the USSR there was socialism and therefore, to begin any major project, you did not need money. The main thing is to have resources and workers. The more goods will be produced - the more money they will be provided. "

Take a casual look at any of Stalin's Five Year Plans and you will see money being referenced in all kinds of investments. The Soviets had a central bank, Gosbank, and many regional banks for the party managerial elite to use. Moreover, the first Stalin Show Trial in 1931 was specifically about bankers allegedly using money and capital in an illegal way. The Soviets never abolished money. Finance capital was controlled by the Party unlike free individuals as in a capitalist country. I understand your anti-revisionist narrative via-a-vis the Soviet Union, but I'm afraid you are wrong.

"What does the great Russian bias mean?"

It means in the way you are actually defending it here, that, simply put, there were alleged patriotic races in the Soviet Union like the Russians, and alleged non-patriotic races like the Western Muslims, whom were ethnically cleansed due to Stalin's appliance of collective guilt, something you are defending. Everyone now understands Stalin, to save his skin, had to resort to Russian patriotism rather than Soviet internationalism because the Soviets were thoroughly overran by the Germans. Moreover, Stalin ethnically cleansed multiple races like the Chechens, Germans, to some extent the Poles in collaboration with the Nazis etc to further cement that he became a Russian nationalist, so much so many White emigres became Stalinist/National Communists.

"I don't know, maybe it was part of the war reparations. Bulgaria has traditionally been an agrarian state and did not have a strong industry"

Probably, and it was somewhat typical of an executive at behest of a victorious nation, not a Marxist internationalist, further showing Stalin had become an aggressive Russian nationalist.

"imperialism means that the USSR creates privileges for itself. Can you name some?"

Politically: using Comintern to direct and overrule other Communist parties, eg forcing the French Communist Party to become Nazi collaborators before Operation Barbarossa. Also refer to the Tito-Stalin split.
Militarily: the right of the Soviets to invade countries to "liberate workers" due to it being a supposed workers' state, starting from Lenin's invasion of Poland with the goal of the Ruhr in Germany. 
Trade: Soviet investment in copper in Mongolia, for instance, where the Soviets were joint owners in copper mines which resulted in the Soviets being able to buy copper below market values. Same is true for Cuba and sugar. Also refer to the Soviet-Albania split.

"It is documented that during Lenin, Soviet democracy was not destroyed. For example, in January 1918, Lenin wanted to make peace with Germany immediately, but the Soviet government did not support him in the framework of a vote - it supported Trotsky‚Äôs point of view "neither peace nor war" and therefore the war was continued. "

There was no such thing as "Soviet democracy" after the Bolshevik coup, financed by the German military and Wall Street. The Kerensky government, which was both liberal and socialist, was the legitimate government. Moreover, by arresting the Mensheviks and Social-Revolutionary parties clearly destroyed any pretense of a "Soviet" government, considering they dominated the Soviets. You're actually referring to a 16 member Politburo decision vis-a-vis Lenin, hardly representing the vast Russian empire. The Bolsheviks never commanded a majority of support from either the workers or peasants, only temporarily gaining some support on a single issue, ending the war. The Bolsheviks not only destroyed the legal, and democratic, government of Russia ran by Kerensky, but also the actual "Soviets".

replies.author: @Mentol_
replies.text:
1. Try to quote any Soviet document that mentions working capital in the USSR. It must be said that money has the goal of increasing itself (the main goal of capital).

2. I said that the USSR had problems with the loyalty of Chechens and Crimean Tatars. This does not mean that other nationalities were non-patriotic. Deportation also does not mean ethnic cleansing, although repression against the Poles was close to this definition.

3. A new concept of Soviet patriotism (a shift in emphasis from traditional internationalism) was created in 1934, not during the war. She largely responded to the threat of Nazism.

4. If you had in mind the cooperation of the NKVD and the Gestapo, then this is a fake that was created by the Russian journalist German Nazarov in the 1990s in one of the anti-Semitic newspapers. Otherwise, you must provide any data on ideological cooperation between the USSR and Germany.

5. Cite any Soviet document that has the goal of increasing the popularity of Russian nationalism in the USSR to the detriment of other nations. I know that this is 100% wrong, and the repressions against the Poles were aimed at reducing the danger to the USSR on the western border, from which the main military threat came for him.

6. Cite the order of the Soviet Communists who tell the French to become Nazi collaborators (WTF).

7. The USSR invaded countries that were in the Soviet zone of influence according to a secret protocol. That is, it was the recovery of the old territories of the Russian empire (not politics) and the elimination of the buffer anti-Soviet cordon. It has nothing to do with chauvinism or privilege, just political pragmatism.

8. Soviet-Polish war began at the initiative of Poland (the attack to the east). Initially, Lenin supported the independence of this state.

9. The October Revolution in Russia was due to an alliance between the Bolsheviks, the Mensheviks and the Social Revolutionaries (coalition).

Information about foreign financing of the Bolsheviks is 100% fake. Today it is part of conspiracy theories.

The Kerensky government lost its support among the people for half a year in 1917 and as a result almost no one defended it.

The left SRs and anarchists fought on the side of the Bolsheviks until the end of the civil war.

If you think that it is possible to win a civil war in a peasant country (Russia) without having any support from these people, then you are greatly mistaken.

10. For the rest, you use the usual demonizing where the Bolsheviks are always the devil who oppresses his own and other nations for no reason. Try to name the positive achievements of these people so that I can see the level of your objectivity.

MajorLeague excuse you, where does Marx EVER say that one should prop themselves up on slave labor, or murder political dissonance, or even that the rich should be manhandled into working? Jfc: for a black person, I'd assumed you'd learned the difference between mutable and immutable qualities someone has. Folks like MLK would be a little appalled by your suggestions that the classes instigated by capitalism and the poor rising against them, are at all comparable to the injustice folks like ourselves face for the color of our skin, good lord. I'd expected better, honestly  (I'm black myself, before you even attempt to pull that shit with me). So let's actually get into it, because you seem to have such a large misunderstanding of how capitalism and marxism work Mr. "I'll only use the broadest definition in the dictionary to define what I mean". 

So onto capitalism first: capitalism is defined as an economic system designed to make as much money(capital) as one can, in as short a time as possible. Typically unregulated, as that tends to slow the money train down. Now, one criticism that I, Marx, and the great MLK had, is that in order for capitalism to succeed, the workers have to be payed less than their work is worth. If I make a sneaker worth 4 bucks, I'm paid a fourth of that. He suggested the best way to counter this, would be for the workers to own the means of production (instead of the state, you jackass. I don't even know how a fucking libertarian such as yourself would confuse the two, unless you're trying to be obstinate ) so that they get to decide how much to sell their work for. 

Marx's point about the bourgeoisie, is not an arbitrary point at all, I don't know how the hell you miss it. This isn't even assuming you agree, fucking who cares, but the way Marx defined it, is as the ones who stand to benefit the most from this system, and actively undermine their workers, to get the most money. The way he saw it, doing things like going against regulations at all cost, including ones designed to protect the worker, such as safety laws, was unjust, and would eventually cause a revolt among the common man, who would: depending on who you ask, either an anarchist, or a democratic socialist; would seize the means of production either using the law, or by force, and then own the means of production directly.

Now, here's where we get into why you're being a jackass, by conflating the two: there is no means of production controlled by the jews, or blacks in Germany. Now, assets, sure, but those aren't stolen and redistributed amongst the people even. They're instead seized by the state, to do whatever they wish with it. The german worker sees nothing of this. This is also forgetting the slave labor aspect. I know you mention how Marx never directly states slave labor is anti marxism, but you then neglect to mention his point that capitalism IS slavery. So you're suggesting that Marx is saying he'd like to use the rich as a surrogate for the poor, and exploit them via unfair working conditions, like slavery. Now, if you respond, and you don't directly refute that last point, really, the biggest and silliest conclusion you're suggesting by saying there's a direct parallel, I will not engage with you. No beating around the bush. Either admit that was wrong, and just go on trying to debate the problems of socialism, or fucking prove that's the end all conclusion Marx had Like, sure, fucking hate socialism if you want, but you deliberately mischaracterize it for political expediency. There's a reason that current folks who want socialism aren't suggesting creating an underclass of minorities to bolster the economy.

replies.author: @diegovelasquez2647
replies.text: MajorLeague Don't you think that socialism is indeed too broad a term to debate over, because essentially what people seem to be debating is finding an essential truth in the language which can easily change, meaning that yes the Nazis sought a nationalist redefinition of socialism, which granted can be categorized as socialist by some, but how left wing is this caracterization of socialism, I mean given that the Nazis were pretty much anti-egalitarianism, radically anti-communist, ultra-nationalist. Of course in the economic axis they were more of a mixed economy. I understand that debating over labels like left-wing and right-wing is futile as well because historically these will and have changed for sure, but what I'm getting at is that Nazism does seem to bring out what we contemporarily would call right-wing, perhaps a form of right-wing socialism, would you agree?

replies.author: @diegovelasquez2647
replies.text: MajorLeague Exactly, it is merging the idea that "socialism" in all its forms must be left-wing, but this simply appears not to be the case, ultimately there seems to be a search for ultimate truth using the dichotomy socialist capitalist or some other senseless dichotomy, which seems not quite apt for politics. Socialism indeed appears in many different forms, and I believe there is not a single definition that encapsulates them all, there may be elements shared by them all, but the broad definition of socialism makes it quite easy to argue that a system was socialist, which makes it sort of useless for contemporary political commentary other than to smear people using that label. It is debatable that Nazi Germany was socialist as it is debatable that Cuba is socialist or that China is socialist, the difference between them I believe is what gives a political meaning to them. Essentially, socialism varies in scope and is not subject to the left-right dichotomy we often use, that's what i'm trying to get at. What could be of use is to judge Nazi Germany in that very dichotomy, as rudimentary as it is, to get a better idea of what it meant to be a nazi, instead of just branding it socialist and labeling it left wing as all "socialism must be"

"Socialism is the science of dealing with the common weal. Communism is not Socialism. Marxism is not Socialism. The Marxians have stolen the term and confused its meaning. I shall take Socialism away from the Socialists. Socialism is an ancient Aryan, Germanic institution. Our German ancestors held certain lands in common. They cultivated the idea of the common weal. Marxism has no right to disguise itself as socialism. Socialism, unlike Marxism, does not repudiate private property. Unlike Marxism, it involves no negation of personality, and unlike Marxism, it is patriotic. We might have called ourselves the Liberal Party. We chose to call ourselves the National Socialists. We are not internationalists. Our socialism is national. We demand the fulfilment of the just claims of the productive classes by the state on the basis of race solidarity. To us state and race are one."

Source: https://en.m.wikiquote.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler (provided by YOU)

Hitler CALLED himself a socialist when it suited him. Big woo. North Korea calls itself a "people's democratic republic." Do you believe that, too, you disingenuous fraud?

Hitler was not a Marxist and hated Marxism, which is what this video correctly contends on that topic. And Hitler FUCKING SAYS IT RIGHT THERE, IN A DIRECT QUOTE TAKEN FROM YOUR OWN LINKED SOURCE. That he CALLED himself a socialist is exactly as irrelevant as if he called himself a turnip. Labels don't really matter; what matters is what they MEAN.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
MajorLeague But he didn't "speak as a socialist." Again, just because he called himself "socialist" doesn't mean he was, any more than the North Korea thing, which is not stupid at all. It's very inconvenient for you, however, and understandably so.

Labels are meaningless by themselves. The American Republican party is not actually republican; it's fascist. The Democratic party is not democratic; it's right-wing plutocratic. America itself is not a democracy or even a "democratic republic" and has not been for a long time; it's an oligarchy.

Hitler could call himself anything he wanted, but that didn't MAKE him that thing. Just because that fact is utterly devastating to your idiotic case doesn't make it any less true.

And no, you DIDN'T meaningfully address this, because you CAN'T. You did say this:

"The idea of a political movement claiming to be socialist when it is not nor intending to be is also irrational and unprecedented"

But that's stupid. Political movements and governments claim to be things they aren't all of the time. There's North Korea as a "people's democratic republic," there's America as a "democracy," and so on. So what? You don't instantly and irrefutably become a thing just in case you call yourself that thing. And yet, that's exactly what you're suggesting.

Your argument seems to basically be:

P1. If a person claims to be a thing, then that person is unquestionably that thing.
P2. Hitler claimed to be a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

From there, you're just spending all of your time pointing your finger at premise number two and crowing victory, as though we all have to accept the first premise as true despite how ludicrous it is. Your logic is utterly moronic.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
MajorLeague That is a lot of text to just post a dictionary definition of the word "socialism" and repeat the argument "you are socialist just in case you say that you are." You didn't need to repeat your argument; I already addressed it and even outlined it in premise-conclusion format for you. Here it is again (slightly reworded to, I hope, improve clarity):

P1. If a person or movement claims to be a thing, then that person or movement is that thing.
P2. Hitler claimed to be a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

Is this NOT your argument? A simple "yes" or "no" would suffice. But if it isn't, then I also need you to tell me HOW it isn't.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
MajorLeague So you can't just give me a "yes" or "no" answer without sidestepping and changing the topic? It's hard to have a discussion about something when the other person refuses to answer simple questions about the position he/she is taking.

I'll say it again for you. Your argument seems to be this:

P1. If a person or movement claims to be a thing, then that person or movement is that thing.
P2. Hitler claimed to be a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

Are you saying that? Because sometimes you seem to be, and sometimes you seem to change your argument and instead suggest that there are specific, independent criteria one meets to be socialist, and Hitler's "socialism" qualifies because it meets those criteria.

In order to even attempt to have a coherent discussion of whatever it is you're claiming, we need to first establish what that actually is. Is your argument the one I presented above? Or is it this one instead?

P1. A person or movement is a thing just in case it possesses certain characteristics.
P2. Hitler had the characteristics necessary to be a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

You see, those are two very different arguments, yet you seem to be claiming BOTH at different times. They can't both be true, though, because they actually contradict one another.

Perhaps you have another, different argument altogether? If so, you'll have to tell me what it is. So far, all I've been able to work out is that you appear to be sometimes claiming that you're a thing just in case you say you're that thing and other times claiming that you're a thing just in case you meet certain criteria ... despite those two claims being actually at odds with one another.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
MajorLeague Yes, yes, I get that you can Google "logical fallacy." You may also want to look up "ad hominem" while you are Googling. And then, once you're done with that, perhaps you might calm yourself and consider answering some simple questions?

After refusing to say whether either of my two proposed arguments were yours (they're both arguments you've made at various points, which is why I suggested them), you said this:

"My argument is that socialism is defined by adherence and identification to itself like most other philosophies."

Well, I'm not quite sure what that actually means. What is "adherence and identification to itself"? Explain it to me.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
‚Äã MajorLeague  Right. Putting aside the personal attacks and your meandering, pretentious use of unnecessarily complicated language to express very simple concepts, let's address the very small sliver of substance in your post, which is to say the first two sentences.

You've defined "adherence" in this context as "belief in and pursuit of its principles." Principles. That's another way, then, of saying that you agree that an ideology (e.g., socialism) actually means certain things, independently of someone simply claiming to be a member of said ideology. "Identification" you have as self-labeling. Fine.

Your argument, then, would appear to be as follows:

P1. A person is a member of an ideology just in case that person both believes and pursues its principles and also identifies him or her self as a member.
P2. Hitler believed and pursued the principles of socialism.
P3. Hitler identified himself as a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

Presumably, you would agree that one cannot be a socialist only by claiming to be one. Curiously, you would also seem to hold that one cannot be a socialist only by believing and pursuing the principles of socialism. Apparently, from what you are telling me, one must both believe and pursue its principles AND claim membership in order to qualify.

Do I have it now? Before we proceed further, it is important to ensure that we're talking about the same thing ... preferably without any more needless digressions.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
‚ÄãMajorLeague Um, that isn't even what "strawman" means. A strawman is a deliberately bad and misrepresented argument constructed in order to attribute it to the other person and then knock it down ... like a "straw man." If you're going to keep spamming logical fallacies you've Googled at people, you should at least try to learn what they actually mean.

I realize, incidentally, that you do that in order to make yourself appear smarter than everyone, but it doesn't work. You exhibit a child's understanding of what an educated person sounds like, and the truth is, you come off as every bit as stupid and uneducated as you actually are. What I'm trying to tell you is that people can see through your bullshit, quite easily in fact.

What I was honestly attempting to do was reconstruct your argument, using what YOU said, in order to discuss it with you. However, it is becoming clear that you aren't serious about discussing it and that the possibility of having your position carefully examined leaves you feeling extremely threatened.

It's useless to attempt to engage in a serious discussion with someone who isn't acting in good faith, as you clearly are not, so I won't waste any more time on you. Instead, I will simply leave a summary of what we've established for anyone who cares to know but doesn't want to have to slog through all of this again:

TL;DR SUMMARY OF OUR DISCUSSION BEGINS HERE

MajorLeague: My argument is that socialism is defined by adherence and identification to itself like most other philosophies.

Me: What is "adherence and identification to itself"?

MajorLeague: Adherence to a philosophy is belief in and pursuit of its principles. Identification with a philosophy is labeling and association of one's self with that philosophy.

Me: Your argument, then, would appear to be as follows:

P1. A person is a member of an ideology just in case that person both believes and pursues its principles and also identifies him or her self as a member.
P2. Hitler believed and pursued the principles of socialism.
P3. Hitler identified himself as a socialist.
C. Hitler was a socialist.

At this point, MajorLeague denies that this is his argument, even though it's literally nothing more than a reconstruction of what we JUST established IS his argument ACCORDING TO HIM. He then goes on to demonstrate that he has no idea what a "strawman" is and that, in the face of serious discussion, his only resort is ad hominem attacks.

/END SUMMARY

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
As a parting point, MajorLeague linked an Oxford definition of socialism:

https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/socialism

"A political and economic theory of social organization which advocates that the means of production, distribution, and exchange should be owned or regulated by the community as a whole."

In other words, doing away with private ownership.

I was going to get to this eventually, but as he lacks the courage of his convictions even to the point of merely taking ownership of his own argument, I'll just do it now. MajorLeague's OWN sources conflict with his claims, as seen here:

https://en.m.wikiquote.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler

"'Our adopted term 'Socialist' has nothing to do with Marxian Socialism. Marxism is anti-property; true socialism is not. Marxism places no value on the individual, or individual effort, of efficiency; true Socialism values the individual and encourages him in individual efficiency, at the same time holding that his interests as an individual must be in consonance with those of the community. All great inventions, discoveries, achievements were first the product of an individual brain. It is charged against me that I am against property, that I am an atheist. Both charges are false."

"Socialism is the science of dealing with the common weal. Communism is not Socialism. Marxism is not Socialism. The Marxians have stolen the term and confused its meaning. I shall take Socialism away from the Socialists. Socialism is an ancient Aryan, Germanic institution. Our German ancestors held certain lands in common. They cultivated the idea of the common weal. Marxism has no right to disguise itself as socialism. Socialism, unlike Marxism, does not repudiate private property."

Doesn't sound very against private property, does he? And indeed the Nazis were not, as the video itself discusses well enough beginning at about 18:00. Yet according to MajorLeague, the Nazis fit the Oxford definition of "a political and economic theory of social organization which advocates that the means of production, distribution, and exchange should be owned or regulated by the community as a whole."

Of course, I think that at this point, we can take what he says with a grain of salt. After all, he ALSO argued that "socialism is defined by adherence and identification to itself like most other philosophies" ... then promptly denied that that was his argument when I began to try to question him about it in detail.

Yeah. I think we're done here.

replies.author: @n0wheregrrl
replies.text:
MajorLeague I literally copied and pasted the definition.

"A political and economic theory of social organization which advocates that the means of production, distribution, and exchange should be owned or regulated by the community as a whole."

The only other option is "regulated by the community as a whole," as opposed to "owned." If you want to weasel out, pretty soon any regulation at all can be called "socialism," and then you're just saying that all regulation ever is socialism, which makes every non-libertarian government ever socialist. Then it just becomes, "Okay, so by that definition, the Nazis were socialist. Also, so what?"

Besides, you already ceded when you refused to accept your own argument. You gave up. You literally outright disowned your OWN argument that you had just stated WAS your argument. It's over. If you want to be taken seriously, then OWN your argument, or else admit that it's not actually your argument after all so that we can start over.

Otherwise, just give up, because anything else is admitting that you have no case.

This is for all you Socialist/ Marxist Sycophants on this thread , Hitler Was a Socialist Who Learned from Karl Marx. Let‚Äôs hear from his own words:


Hitler on Marxism
‚ÄúNational Socialism derives from each of the two camps the pure idea that characterizes it, national resolution from bourgeois tradition; vital, creative socialism from the teaching of Marxism.‚Äù ‚Äì 

January 27, 1934, interview with Hanns Johst in Frankforter Volksblatt

Hitler on Teaching Socialism
‚ÄúThere is a difference between the theoretical knowledge of socialism and the practical life of socialism. People are not born socialists, but must first be taught how to become them.‚Äù ‚Äì 

October 5, 1937, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Capitalism
‚ÄúIn those countries, it is actually capital that rules; that is, nothing more than a clique of a few hundred men who possess untold wealth and, as a consequence of the peculiar structure of their national life, are more or less independent and free. They say: ‚ÄòHere we have liberty.‚Äô By this they mean, above all, an uncontrolled economy, and by an uncontrolled economy, the freedom not only to acquire capital but to make absolutely free use of it. That means freedom from national control or control by the people both in the acquisition of capital and in its employment. This is really what they mean when they speak of liberty. These capitalists create their own press and then speak of the ‚Äòfreedom of the press.‚Äô In reality, every one of the newspapers has a master, and in every case this master is the capitalist, the owner. This master, not the editor, is the one who directs the policy of the paper. If the editor tries to write other than what suits the master, he is ousted the next day. This press, which is the absolutely submissive and characterless slave of the owners, molds public opinion. Yes, certainly, we jeopardize the liberty to profiteer at the expense of the community, and, if necessary, we even abolish it.‚Äù ‚Äì 

December 10, 1940, speech in Berlin

Hitler on Socialism
‚ÄúSocialism as the final concept of duty, the ethical duty of work, not just for oneself but also for one‚Äôs fellow man‚Äôs sake, and above all the principle: Common good before own good, a struggle against all parasitism and especially against easy and unearned income. And we were aware that in this fight we can rely on no one but our own people. We are convinced that socialism in the right sense will only be possible in nations and races that are Aryan, and there in the first place we hope for our own people and are convinced that socialism is inseparable from nationalism.‚Äù ‚Äì 

August 15, 1920, speech in Munich at the Hofbr√§uhaus.

replies.author: @treeplanter-bv4gw
replies.text:
PlueschQQ¬† >so your argument is under the same circumstances as the dprk France would do the same things? 
Yes, obviously it would, because for France to be in the exact same situation as the DPRK /it would have to be the DPRK/. If France were under *similar* situations to the DPRK, though, it would do *similar* things, namely repression of political dissidents, state control of industry, focus on agriculture and geopolitical grandstanding in order to affect change on the sanctions against it. France is different to the DPRK in ideology, but ideology means little to the state and its rulers. The conditions a state is subjected to determine its reaction.

>Even if you were right that first assertion
Oh good, you're at least considering my poin-
>which you aren't
oh alright then

>it wouldn't have any bearing on wether France is less repressive than the dprk *right now*.
Like I said, France exports its oppression. Just because one state is less oppressive than another doesn't mean that state is actually, materially, better than the other. They're both bad, because both are oppressive. That is what is important.

> And what does your point about imprisoning not being just because I think it is just even mean. Yeah sure unless you accept absolute morality what you say is true but this again has no bearing on wether nearly everyone would agree that the French prison and legal system is lightyear's ahead of the north korean.

It means that you agree with France's prisons, but not with the DPRK's, because you align ideologically with France. I, on the other hand, disagree with both prison systems, because both are enacting systemic violence against their populaces in service to an unjustified hierarchy. And because I know this is going to be a sticking point for you, violence is the limiting of the autonomy of an individual, and there can indeed be justified violence, but it does have to justify itself. Both France and the DPRK do exert justified violence on, for instance, rapists, but this is in service to greater unjustified hierarchies, and so a whole hell of a lot of unjust violence occurs in both states.

 I do not need to list what unjust violence the DPRK performs, since we've all heard the defector accounts, but France has the same problems as every single capitalist country: there are more empty homes than homeless people, and yet squatting is illegal. Homelessness is also punished, where public spaces which homeless people use, such as park benches have been removed by the French state, in service to the wealthy. If you try and alleviate your homelessness, by squatting in an empty house that is being held by a bank or wealthy landowner as an investment, you will be evicted by the police and charged by the state. You cannot live outside, because once again, the spaces you try and occupy are being attacked by the state, forcing you further and further away from civilisation, and thus any chance of "working your way up", as the liberals of fond of telling those in situations like this. This state of affairs affects an estimated 140 000 people in France, including 30 000 children. While not on the same scale as the DPRK's oppression, *it is still oppression*. Add to this the discord sown by French arms trading, and foreign interventions in MENA, as well as the continued violence it exerts against its former colonies, and France's total oppression? I'd say it's greater in scope than the DPRK.

replies.author: @Budzilla24
replies.text: There is a very good book "Democracy in Chains" by Nancy Maclean that elucidates the origin of these talking points. Basically, rich white men want to own everything, but standing in their way is the threat of democracy; the threat that all those dirty have-nothings might band together to take what the rich white guys stole. But this isn't a very popular way of framing the issue, obviously, so the rich white guys shift the argument from 'gimme moar!' to 'the rights of the minority must be defended from the tyranny of the majority'. Then you're not arguing for the powerful to have more power, but for the untrammeled rights of the individual to live free of the oppressive, 'collectivist' mob rule. Of course this completely delegitimizes any form of societal say on distribution of wealth, where wealth is properly the surplus production of the economy (being a social phenomenon) and NOT the profits of the owners of capital. But yeah, these political arguments are why many think 'democracy=mob rule' and 'republic=enlightened, rights-having liberty-loving Americanism'

Antonio Notmyrealnamo - of course if I was to debate a Christian theist I would start with their belief in the supernatural and such. but I was only using that as an analogy for this instance. so the comparison is simply the different beliefs between different sects. so while all Christian sects hold supernatural beliefs, they have many beliefs that are contradictory or ones that are present in some sects but absent in others

for example:
I cannot argue against beliefs of Catholicism if I am debating against a Protestant. take sainthood for instance. Catholics worship saints and raise certain people to sainthood. however, a Protestant person does not believe in sainthood and most (if not all) Protestant sects do not include the raising of individuals to status of 'saint' as in Catholicism. this is an important distinction because some Protestants argue that Catholic saint worship is idolatry and blasphemous and they are going to hell for worshiping saints. some Protestants even argue that Catholics aren't even Christians because they worship saints. this is a matter of life or death because if one is correct and the other is not, one of them could be doomed to supposedly going to hell. but no one knows because Christians can't agree on shit lol. but just as the same with things like baptism, not all Christian sects require baptism. so if I am debating against someone who is a Christian in a sect that does not include baptism, I cannot argue against baptism in this specific debate because my opponent does not adhere to that belief. so it is incredibly important to distinguish between different sects because they hold some different specific beliefs, whether it be Catholicism, Protestantism, Baptists, Methodists, Lutheranism, Calvinism, etc. they share many of the same beliefs, but they also have starkly different ones as well even though they all fall under the umbrella of "Christianity"

same for Marxism. I cannot argue against beliefs of Trotskyism or Stalinism if I am debating against a Marxist. so say we take 'authoritarian government' and state tyranny for instance. Trotskyism, Stalinism, Maoism include authoritarian governments and state tyranny. however, a Marxist person who adheres to the teachings of Karl Marx does not believe in these things, they would be advocates for the abolition of the state as Marx did and as Marxism inherently includes. (Marxism-communism: "classless, stateless, money-less society"). this is of course an important distinction because people who argue against tyrannical authoritarian government in a debate against a Marxist would be disingenuous and intellectually dishonest because a Marxist believes the state should not exist. so when people talk about Marxism and then they say "authoritarian tyrannical government", it is an inherent contradiction. so if I am debating against someone who is a Marxist who adheres to the belief of abolishing the state, I cannot then argue against state abuse of power or authoritarianism in this specific debate because my opponent does not believe in that. it is INCREDIBLY important to distinguish between different ideologies because they hold some different specific beliefs, whether it be classical Marxism, anarcho-communism, anarcho-socialism, Stalinism, Maoism, Leninism, Trotskyism, Sovietism, etc. they can share some of the same beliefs, but they also have starkly different beliefs as well even though they all fall under the umbrella of "Marxism"

"There's nothing wrong with the discussion of the minutiae of collectivist schools of thought, but I think you're conflating that with the discussion of their real world application."

>I'm not. in fact, if we actually take a realistic view of history, I am applying the actual tenets of these ideologies rather than conflating them with what happens in practice. discussing the minutiae is important in this case, and very important in politics. just like this video said "Hitler was a socialist liberal". he cannot be both of those things because the ideologies have contradictory beliefs within them. listen to Professor Michael Parenti, he is the best person I have heard discussing these things. just like a Christian can be a Protestant or a Catholic, discussing the small differences is important because they have contradictory beliefs like baptism and sainthood. discussing the differences is important in politics and Marxism because there is classical Marxism that adheres to Marx's teachings and there are ideologies that came after by different people and a classical Marxist would believe in the abolition of the state (belief that a state should not exist) versus a Stalinist or a Maoist who would believe in authoritarian rule and tyrannical government. these are contradictory beliefs because one involves a state abusing its power and the other involves the abolishing of the state. the reason why is extremely prevalent because Marx despised governments and advocated for abolition of the state because of exactly what happened after him. he hated the abuse of power, he hated the fact that the state has a monopoly on the use of violence, he hated bureaucrats and oligarchic corruption of governments, and he believed the state only exists to protect the interests of the ruling class (the bourgeoisie)

11 That all unearned income, and all income that does not arise from work, be abolished.
12 Since every war imposes on the people fearful sacrifices in blood and treasure, all personal profit arising from the war must be regarded as treason to the people. We therefore demand the total confiscation of all war profits.
13 We demand the nationalization of all trusts.
14 We demand profit-sharing in large industries.
15 We demand a generous increase in old-age pensions.
16 We demand the creation and maintenance of a sound middle-class, the immediate communalisation of large stores which will be rented cheaply to small trades people, and the strongest consideration must be given to ensure that small traders shall deliver the supplies needed by the State, the provinces and municipalities.

"'Socialist' I define from the word 'social; meaning in the main ‚Äòsocial equity‚Äô. A Socialist is one who serves the common good without giving up his individuality or personality or the product of his personal efficiency. I guess it basically centered on how the Democrats and this video mislead people into believing Hitler was a capitalist. And then the 2nd debate was the idea that Republicans are racist or more racist than the Democrats. 
I'll dive into both of these again. 

There is no way (no hard proof or witness testimonies) that actually suggest that hitler was a 'pure' capitalist, the best that you could come up with is that he was inconsistent in his economic beliefs (which means he occasionally adopted some capitalistic polices). Hitler allowed for some pivate land ownership, however i have already said that this does not automically make Nazi Germany a capitalist state as private land ownership isn't a trait that's exclusive to capitalism when you look at all the democratic socialist countries today that allow privitization. Hitler's Germany still contradicted capitalism in many ways, such as, lack of variable interest rates, assigning work instead of allowing people to choose, lack of free trade, etc. The 2nd main argument that is presented is that Hitler knocked off the so called "socialists" in his Nazi party. Hitler motivation for the night of the long knives was to increase his power/influence, not to rid the party of its socialists influences. This isn't the first time that a political leader knocked off his counterparts or even people that agreed with him, stalin killed communists/socialists.  Now at the same time, I have said that Hitler isn't a pure socialist either. Facism and Nazism are a little different, but Nazism is very different from pure capitalism and socialist. There really is no real racial element to socialism or capitalism. Capitalism, especially the lassiz-faire form of capitalism is SMALL government control, and hitler's germany simply had too much government intervention (social reform) to be considered actual capitalism. A capitalistic government is suppose to let the markets/people dictate the ebb and flow of the economy.
Plus for someone who was so capitalistic in Adolf Hitler he seemed to be pretty critical of the system and pretty contradictory. Just read the 25 point plan.

As far as American politics are concerned, i think both parties are racist to a certain extent, but the gerneral platform of both parties are to put society as a whole in a good position.

replies.author: @ludwigvonmiseswasright4380
replies.text:
Pasha Staravoitau "The famine, though never intentional, did take away 3-5million people"....wow.  
The Holodomor (Ukrainian: to kill by starvation") was a man-made famine in Soviet Ukraine in 1932 and 1933 that killed millions of Ukrainians. It is also known as the Terror-Famine and Famine-Genocide in Ukraine. It was part of the wider Soviet famine of 1932‚Äì33, which affected the major grain-producing areas of the country. During the Holodomor, millions of inhabitants of Ukraine, the majority of whom were ethnic Ukrainians, died of starvation in a peacetime catastrophe unprecedented in the history of Ukraine

According to the findings of the Court of Appeal of Kiev in 2010, the demographic losses due to the famine amounted to 10 million, with 3.9 million direct famine deaths, and a further 6.1 million birth deficit.

Some scholars believe that the famine was planned by Joseph Stalin to eliminate a Ukrainian independence movement. Using Holodomor in reference to the famine emphasises its man-made aspects, arguing that actions such as rejection of outside aid, confiscation of all household foodstuffs, and restriction of population movement confer intent, defining the famine as genocide; the loss of life has been compared to that of the Holocaust.

replies.text:
I think by my profile picture, it should be clear I'm not a fan of mussolini. But, what exactly do you find so "unacceptable" about calling democracy, at least in its corrupted parlamentary form, "mob rule"? 

It seems to me to be similar to saying it is a "popularity contest" when it comes to elections, which it obviously is. Elections aren't a show of quality, and for an unbelievable amount of them, it seems there are not required levels of competency or anything similar. 

Not saying there should be that, that could definitely be abused. But in the end, all that matters is who the "mob" wants to "rule" although mob is just the majority, and in most cases not everyone votes in an election, so more accurately it is a semi-large minority. 

I'm an anarchist, so I'm obviously not in favor of EITHER Fascist dictatorship or parlamentary democracy. I would, of course, prefer the latter, but that doesn't mean we can't critique the latter and try to achieve better alternatives like council democracy or forms of anarchist horizontal organisation.

replies.author: @LordKnightcon
replies.text:
@nota8863 It's on account of language of libertarian left having been co-opted and it's meaning and intent changed into something else.

When classical anarchist philosophy criticizes democracy, it does so with the purpose of highlighting problems with centralized political power. When someone on the far right today does the same, it's because they are completely authoritarian, and dislike democracy for it's tendency towards decentralization.

I think the ideal system is one where society is governed by consensus, rather than a group who can acquire "the most" votes getting to tell everyone else what to do. To that end, my criticism of liberal politics comes not in the form of being in favor of something undemocratic, but rather pointing out that it is not "democratic *enough*, in that it doesn't even impose the will of the majority, but rather the wills of the elite, and from there highlight that trying to enforce your will on others is always going to fail.

Democracy is an ideal that should be aspired to, rather than a codified political system. Even if we were to successfully replace a capitalist state with a democratic socialist state, I would continue opposing the remaining power of that state and advocating for increased mutual aid in communities.

@pspspspssspspps¬† What a fruitful conversation; you are also very fascinating to me! I believe we have different definitions or understandings of the word ideology; I would define it rather broadly. Any set of ideas and values which are connected together and somewhat coherent, I think, could be classified as an ideology. As you have ideas and values, I assume, you have a corresponding ideology. Your very own ideology, which you most likely share with noone exactly; everyone has different values and different ideas. But we all borrow, more or less, from existing ideas and form our own opinions about things which already exist. You mention religion and seem to see it critically; would you not consider this part of an "atheist" ideology, or at least an idea that is "adjacent"? If you don't, and you in fact value religion, this could also be a part of your ideology. Either way, religious or not, both are conceptions which correspond to something ideological. 

I don't think ideology is narrowing; it is a method of categorizing and understanding. I, obviously, value anarchism and the corresponding values and ideas. Yet, I still read lots of marxist and communist literature, and engage with many "mainstream" works of art.

replies.author: @dynamicworlds1
replies.text:
The free market place of ideas is a good thing, but we're missing an important part: teaching critical thinking and logical fallacies.

Hiding people from bad ideas is basically impossible in the information age, so we need to treat it like we do with disease exposure and inoculate people by bolstering their mental immune systems.

The most dangerous ideas and propaganda techniques are simply the ones we haven't learned to deal with, but teaching how to is not an impossible task at all.

Just make recognizing logical fallacies part of reading comprehension on standardized tests and most of the problem will start to take care of itself (though our current politicians will never do that as they rely on propaganda rather than policy to stay in office)

This https://agloa.org/propaganda/ is also a great help and I'm very glad to have been exposed to it as a kid in an extracurricular program, as my public school (dispite being one of the best in the area) taught basically no critical thinking and I never encountered a description of one logical fallacy until college.

"No but seriously. I'm not going to spend a half hour reading quotes from Adolf Hitler's speeches. "
Heh.  If it takes you half an hour to read that much, that certainly explains your posts.  But hey, anything to avoid the evidence, I guess.

"Ofc he was trying to appeal to the common man. Ofc he wanted people to think he had the interests of the workers in mind. You know who else does that? Every person who has ever been in politics."
Funny thing; most of them can do that without endorsing or enacting socialism.  Mostly because socialism has nothing to do with helping the common man or the workers, but also because they aren't socialist.

"Hitler was not a Socialist. In fact, he hated the ideas of both Communism and Socialism"
Bullshit.  If he wasn't a socialist, he wouldn't have constantly praised it, made it part of his political platform, or nationalized industries.

Every Leftist but one, then!

Did the DPRK enact democracy and repeatedly state their love of democracy and opposition to socialism?

Any argument that Hitler was not a socialist would disqualify the large majority of other socialist regimes.

replies.text:
The funny part about the idea that Hitler pretended to be socialist isn't just that it's blatant bullshit, but the question why. 

There's plenty of reason for a socialist to pretend he's not a socialist--the constant failure, the tyranny, the starvation, the hundred-plus million murders, the environmental devastation, and so on. But that a non-socialist would pretend to be socialist is just silly.

A rapist may well pretend to be innocent to calm a woman's fears. But what innocent man would be insane enough to think he could improve his love-life by pretending to be a rapist?

replies.author: @Kingoftherednex
replies.text:
"You're forgetting that this isn't today we're talking about. Socialism was thought of in the 30's very differently than it is today."
Not really.  It was always a fringe party ready to use violence to achieve its ends because it would never get public support.

""Any argument against Hitler being a Socialist would also disqualify the majority of other regimes" Really? Because I don't recall Capitalists making record profits under Lenin, Stalin, Mao, or Castro."
You should, because several people--including Lenin, Stalin, Mao, and Castro themselves, became filthy rich under socialism.

(Also, you're not going to read actual evidence when it's shove under your nose, but you expect me to go reading Jacobinmag?  I did, and he tried to make an argument out of the fact that hopeful people make the stock market go up, but still; kinda funny.)

"Hitler only furthered privatization in Germany. The exact opposite of what a Socialist would do."
Except here in the real world the German government privatized industries that it had no choice to when they were in desperate need of money, and stole far more than they sold.  The USSR also privatized several industries before they collapsed--even farms.  China and Vietnam have done the same--and like their fellow socialists in Germany, they did so because they had no choice.  Even Cuba privatized its water industry and some of its tourism.

So "the exact opposite of what a socialist would do" turns out to be what *all* of them do.

"but but but... you're assuming that everyone on the left just throws out the word "racist" every time someone disagrees with them."
And the Left keeps proving him right!

"all mainstream media" like Fox News you mean."
Yeah, because who can forget when Fox helped a candidate cheat during debates....

Oh, wait; that was CNN.

Well, there's the time they doctored video to replace someone's answer with awkward silence, so...

Well, crap, that was NBC.

But we got 'em on that time they slandered a sitting president with blatantly forged documents during an election year--that was a pretty obvious one for...

...for CBS.  Well, damn.

Not to worry, though, I still got the knockout punch--remember that time they cut-and-pasted audio to create a racist statement where none existed from a defendant in a murder trial?  Damn those bastards at...

...at MSNBC.  

But we at least have one--back when Stalin was still doing the socialist thing (wait, lemme guess, Stalin wasn't socialist either?), FOX News was busy shilling for him, pretending the Holodomor didn't exist and claiming his show-trials were eamples of due process.  Just what you'd expect from...

...from the New York Times.

So yeah--"your news source is a lot more honest than mine!" isn't exactly the biting insult you were lookin' for.

"I also fail to see what your argument has to do with Hitler not being a Socialist."
Because we keep watching Leftists try to pretend that Hitler was the next Milton Friedman as a way to slander people.

"My opinions are based on Hitler's actions. Not what the News says."
No they ain't.  Your opinions are based on a need to No-True-Scotsman away the horrors of a socialist regime.

replies.author: @DrCruel
replies.text:
Never heard of that one. The one I heard of involved seizing all private lands and turning them into state-run communes. Peasants in 1920 were so furious about the betrayal of the promise of "free land' that they rose up in open revolt, and Lenin was forced to back down. It was for this reason that Stalin later orchestrated the massive enforced famine called the Holodomor in the early 1930s, finally breaking the power of the farmers after killing millions of them, their families and their children. Thereafter Bolshevik agriculture was a mess (a later "reform", allowing farmers to work their own personal plots in addition to the communal farms, helped alleviate matters - although these tiny plots accounted for about 2-3% of cultivated land in the Bolshevik Empire, they yielded about 25% of the agricultural output).

I really do suggest you do some more reading about agriculture under the Bolsheviks. It's pretty grim stuff.

replies.author: @JacatackLP
replies.text: DrCruel I suggest you read some *actual* Soviet Agricultural history. First off the Communes were given state directives but they were owned and run by the workers who ran it. It wasn‚Äôt the peasantry who rose up it was the landowners. Collectivization wasn‚Äôt enforced until after the famine that was in no way orchestrated by the Soviets, unless you‚Äôre suggesting they were magical and could ruin the harvest across Eastern Europe including Poland and other non soviet states, with the difference being that while those nations could trade for food, where as the USSR was under such ridiculous sanctions they could only buy from other countries using grain. In fact it was the fact that the wealthy landowners had been burning crops and killing cattle to inflate prices in a time of famine that LEAD to collectivization of the farms. And the Soviets saved the people of the Ukraine by draining the Eastern grain reserves leaving the East open to Japanese invasion, a very real threat of the time, trace the sources of your Holodomor myth and all you‚Äôll find is fascists

replies.author: @Reed-Media
replies.text:
"state control of institutions and authoritarianism" 


First, where do you think those institutions come from? The State has always controlled them, the State is made of those institutions. Democratic Socialism just gives the public means of production FOR those institutions through democratic vote. Don't lump authoritarianism in there just because history shows us that socialistic societies can produce fascism. Capitalism does this also! 

However, the way the Left has operated in the current system is on occasion equally if not more deplorable than behavior of the right particularly in US politics (Not sure about Brazil). But the idea of "brainwashing combined with weak minds" producing socialism is arrogant and reductive and equally ignorant of the history of BOTH sides of the political spectrum.

replies.author: @Reed-Media
replies.text:
Well this will be a difficult conversation to have considering we have completely different definitions of certain concepts. I'll start here as it seems to be a big point of discourse: Hate speech is real. Revoking the platform of someone with antiquated and violent ideology, while it is globalist and leftist, is not violent intrinsically, as is the hate speech itself. But I'll give it to you, the examples you cited are violent on the part of the UK and Germany, and that is something those sovereign nations must tackle, though i really don't blame them for making such decisions, especially considering Germany's past. England will probably end up using their surveillance system to get rid of all the people of colour anyway, who are we kidding? But private entities such as Google, Facebook, Twitter can act as they wish, they don't set a precedent for other businesses. The government didn't mandate that decision, those corporations did. Besides, there are plenty of conservative platforms that block and curate liberal speech to their own agenda. Is that fascist behavior? To me that's people pursuing capitalist gain by appealing to the confirmation bias that most people have regarding their political beliefs. 
As for private corporations becoming federalized, it doesn't seem that private enterprise or free market must be sacrificed in order to make certain voted-for institutions socialized. It doesn't have to be all in, where ALL private enterprise is socialized. And the state should be wary of dangerous ideological organizations, but that's not to say that anyone who is a Nazi sympathizer should be legally punished for holding such beliefs, regardless of the fact I personally believe they should. 

As for Socialism itself, saying that it will fail on ideology alone is pure speculation on your part, and while you do have history on your side, it's impossible to prove that socialist policy as an exclusive abstract concept is a direct cause for fascism. Capitalism has facilitated violent fascists as well my friend, regardless of what they call themselves. Look at the civil war that the US is funding and perpetuating in Yemen by proxy of funding Saudi Arabia, all due to nuanced trade policy regarding arms and oil and a capitalist agenda that puts product and monetary value over human life. And to be honest, No, people can't control themselves. I don't trust you to do the right thing no more than you trust me to do the right thing. Regardless, we all have a base set of needs (food, clothing, shelter) that can be met through social organization of federal funds and institutions, and denying those things to everyone just because you can "do it yourself" is selfish to those who cannot pull themselves up by their bootstraps due to a vast array of reasons. And just because people have used similar Socialist institutions to assume authoritarian regimes doesn't mean that the ideas themselves were flawed. We can have it both ways! We can keep microbreweries and fucking McDonalds and still give people healthcare and a good education! You're making it an all or nothing thing, and that is the ESSENTIAL difference between Absolute Socialism and Democratic Socialism. Most all historical socialist turned into fascism because the public wasn't involved aside from throwing full political support TO a fascist, or there was heavy conspiratorial prejudice on the part of the States that implemented such policies.  

And holding those beliefs doesn't make me a sheep that's sucking on the teat of big government, and it doesn't make me a fascist sympathizer just because fascists have used socialism to gain authoritarianism. It makes me someone who sees that there is already an incredible gap between how much wealth is accumulated by society and the people who are actually benefiting from that wealth. I can see the potential in the system that exists because it does have good bones, but people have to organize and take control of it. It has always been for the purpose of serving those who hold the power, and it always will until the bridge is built between government spending and the people it is being spent on. Democratically elected social spending could be a way to bridge that gap! Also unions working with those institutions to forge policy that benefits those groups idk just throwing things out there

@Dav
I'm a gay guy and I really feel the need to share this with you after reading your responses to 8xil in this thread
I might come across as rude and "in your face" but that's just part of my culture as a Dutch, so don't take offence. If I would want to offend you I would let you know explicitly and I would make sure it hits hard. 
I hope you are willing to be open-minded and learn from my response to you.

Here are some observations I have for you:
You are piss-poor at debating and you really make no sense at all. You do not make a strong case for your POV most of the time.
You fail to answer questions, you provide no evidence for claims you make , you deflect, you project and you conflate. You also need to learn to use paragraphs when you try to have a written conversation unless you want to come across as nothing more than just a ranting lunatic. Even when you are on a smartphone.

Here's the conversational part of my comment:
Look, all I really want from you (and others like you) is to leave gay people alone and do not conflate people with a certain sexual preference (in this case, homosexuals) with people with gender-confusion.
If you really are so willing to oblige people, then oblige me and stop putting me in one category with people with whom I have absolutely nothing in common.

So... homosexuality =/= gender-confusion 
The two should not be lumped together. 
Are we clear on that?

Also, if you think (like the pro-gender-confusion hardliners do) that everyone should just accept the entire gender-confusion agenda and go along with it or else "face consequences" then I, as a gay guy, will indeed accuse you of being a fascist.

Now, darling sweetie darling, don't be upset if my tone sounds harsh because that's just the inevitable consequence of the limited form of communication that is the YT comments section, in combination with my Dutch culture.
