replies.author: @stonytina01will-not-be-ban78
replies.text:
@Dav
Hey dude. Thanks for your response. 
You've mentioned a lot but I shall address only as few of those things, for the sake of brevity.

First and foremost: people with mental issues do not deserve physical violence, from no one. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About identity
People are not born with an identity. Identity is (partly) the self-image someone has. This self-image is not innate, it develops as the person grows older.
As far as I know, up until two minutes ago, the DSM-5 still labelled the mismatch between gender-identity and the actual genitals of a person as a mental disorder. 
I have many objections to the incorrect and ineffective way the medical field treats those people; that treatment has been moulded by PC views and it only exacerbates the problems. I will address only a few of my objections here.

1. Psychiatry (better put: the APA) has sadly been infested with intellectual dishonesty and "political correctness driven by the current zeitgeist", ever since 50s and it went on from there.
Good practice in psychiatry dictates that psychiatrists should not "play along" with people with identity disorders. 
Except when it comes to gender identity.

2. Giving surgery to people with gender-identity issues is as detrimental as giving liposuction to anorexic chicks. Look at the insanely high prevalence of suicide. Clearly, the approach of surgery has failed. 
In the early days of psychiatry, certain mental disorders were "treated" with lobotomy. As the pharma industry developed better medication at the (informal) request of the field of psychiatry, the psychiatrists steered clear from lobotomy. The same should be done with people with gender-issues. No more butchering up patients through surgery, but more research into and development of better medication. That has been the goal of psychiatry for every mental disorder. 
Except when it comes to gender identity.

3. The ultimate goal of psychiatry never has been and never will be to make people happy (happiness after treatment is just an added bonus). The ultimate goal of psychiatry is to make patients function as well as possible in a society, or to reduce the dysfunction to a minimum level.
Except when it comes to gender identity.

Psychiatry has failed those people time and time again. 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'd like to make clear I should not have accused you personally of acting like a fascist. I should have known better than to lump an individual together with a group. 
However, there are definitely people that are starting to act creepy.

"...there is a 'T' in 'LGBT'. If you do not consider yourself affiliated with LGBT because of the T, that's your business, and I will not act like a fascist and say that you have to believe otherwise."

Are you able to see you are already forcing me to share your view by lumping me together with the "LGBT" label? 
Are you able to see that the LGBT label is made up? It's not a real physical entity such as gravitational pull or the wavelength=spectrum for sunlight. It's been arbitrarily decided by a bunch of people. 
Can you imagine it's as annoying as christians calling me a sinner, even though I don't even share their concept of sin?
Now add to that last question the notion of how this LGBT label is shoved down EVERYONE else's throat. 

Look at what's happening in Canada with their ridiculous mandatory-use-of-pronouns law. The State is forcing people to accept "the trannie-agenda" or "face consequences".
Look at the case in California where an employee in a care home was sentenced to a $100,000 fine for "misgendering" someone. Now add to this case the current (and highly laughable) concept of gender-fluidity, where someone can change his mind from minute to minute.

Damn.. I ran out of time for the rest... I really have to do some RL stuff now... I will come back to this later on, if you'd like that.

replies.author: @berjanbeen7188
replies.text:
stonytina01 will-not-be-banned
Usually when the DSM is used for a diagnosis it means that the person being diagnosed is already having difficulties that effect their lives. Kind of like how you don't need to call a plumber if your toilet is working fine. It also not really a condemnation of their condition, but rather a indication that this thing is effecting this person and treatment might be needed. That treatment can also be to have the person in question to transition to their identified gender. 
Likewise having ADHD doesn't have to be problematic so medication and treatment might not be necessary unless it starts having an adverse effect on the person's life. 

1. From what I gather (only) looking things up on the Internet it's not as simple as you paint it to be. Before they "play along" (as you call it), they have to account for other disorders and the psychology of why they want that change (for example because of certain advantage the gender identity has or because they haven't accepted their homosexuality).

2. The comparison with lobotomy is a rather crude one. Lobotomy was a crude surgery on the intricate and complex brain. Whereas gender reassignment surgery deals with less complex, better understood body parts. 
Not to mention that a larger part of the reassignment is hormone treatments and surgery is not always performed. 
Also studies show that the gender reassignment does indeed help with the gender-dysphoria. After the procedure and surgery these people do have less stress from being in the wrong body. 
The rate of suicides isn't associated with their gender-dysphoria, but from social factors such as not being accepted by friends and family and discrimination (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0924933817318357). 

3. Again you are misconstruing why people come to psychiatry in general. Mostly they come when there are already problems with which they can't seem to deal appropriately with. Despite your insistence that the treatment for transgender people isn't aimed at getting these people to function better in society and to help them reduce the way their problems are effecting them, that is exactly what is happening. 

Also you are seriously misconstruing what is said in the Canadian Bill. All it does is add trans-gender people to the classes that are protected under current discrimination laws. Meaning that they receive the same protections from discriminations as many minority groups (such as homosexuals) currently receive under Canadian law. This does not involve mandatory use of pronouns, despite what YouTube reactionaries might want you to believe. It does for example protect them if they are fired for being transgender. 
Also the case you mention, is conspicuously absent from the web. I do find some references to a law being passed in California in which health-care professionals could be fined for discrimination for willfully and continuously misgendering transgender people (max $1000,-). Notice the willfully part to see that the law is more nuanced that you are letting on. Though I do think proving intent in such a case is hard and as such the law seems to be little more than symbolic.

I do find it ironic that someone who's sexuality is likely to have been dismissed at least once in his life and is part of a group that for years were considered mentally ill and in need of being cured, can't even consider that a transgender person could be facing similar.

replies.author: @steffenjensen422
replies.text:
"The term "Fascism" was first used in 1915 by members of Mussolini's movement, the Fasci of Revolutionary Action." So maybe Moussolini didn't invent it himself, but it certainly was his group that did so, therefore my argument still stands.
On the issue of private businesses. There were a lot of private businesses in Nazi Germany. In fact, there were almost no state businesses - after the Nazis privatised most that existed before. These private businesses had independence and signed quite favorable treaties with the government, which paid them money while being in debt - which would make no sense, if the businesses weren't actually private. It was only later in the war that the Nazis regulation got tighter, because they needed to cramp out as much war material as possible - as I said, quite common in a war - and still businessmen owned their own businesses and could make their own decisions. Ever heard of Oskar Schindler? He used that power to save hundrets of jews, which would have been unthinkable, had his business actually been run by Nazis.
And please don't mention PragerU. It's a far-right big-business lobbying organisation and I have yet to encounter a single good video from them (believe me, I've seen many). Also, that's not how it works. I have already seen and heard virtually every argument from the far-right on this issue, and I'm not gonna just watch more footage of people telling me the same lies again. If you want me to debunk any specific argument, I'll do that for you, but you're gonna have to research the arguments yourself.

Lastly, it's sometimes hard to understand what you are writing - please use proper punctuation and put a little effort into communicating clearly, thanks!

author: @whosiskid
text:
I used to walk my German Shepherd (not related to the issue at hand) along the beach north of Loyola "University in Chicago. I became friends with a woman from Germany who worked in the German Consulate there. We got to talking about Americans' knowledge of Germany and I mentioned to her that some Americans think that Hitler was a socialist and/or liberal. She broke into absolutely hysterical laughter, thinking I had made a joke about how dumb those on the right could be, until I assured her that I was serious. Her next comment was, "Have they read his speeches?" And of course they haven't. They foist obtuse reasons on top of that ridiculous "Nazi SOCIALIST" comment. Hitler called it the Socialist Workers' party. Not sure how he could be "Workers" when the first thing he did, almost, was end the labor unions. Not exactly a "workers" kind of thing to do. And Hitler did not attempt to recruit any Leftists of any kind to his movement, but instead went after other far right groups. 

What really lies behind these ridiculous statements by Crowder and others is an attempt at one and the same time to rid the Right of their greatest shame and saddle the Left with it instead. Invariably, these people know nothing about the Nazis. They just latch upon some inexact ideas and a word or two and run with it.

author: @SidheKnight
text:
For the record, the USA is a democracy. And a republic. The terms "democracy" and "republic" are not mutually exclusive.

Most western countries are democratic republics. The only exceptions are those that are constitutional monarchies.

I think this need of the right-wing to demonize the term democracy is because "majority rule" is not compatible with "rule by the 1%" (through money in politics and campaign donations).

replies.text:
*a representative "democracy" which isn't real democracy*
Why not? A democracy is a rule "by the people". In theory, a typical modern representative republic is governed by the people in that they have (limited and well defined) control over the people in power. How is it not "real"? 

You might just as well say a constitutional monarchy isn't a "real" monarchy.

*Once the new ruler takes office he/she can make decisions without the peoples consent*

replies.author: @Kapita_Lismus
replies.text: Just saying democracy is mob rule is way too simple. A common easy definition is democracy = rule of the "people". But what is the people? The majority or ALL of the people? The former where "the majority" rule would often be called a populist democracy.

replies.author: @lanefunai4714
replies.text:
MajorLeague It has been observed that a pure democracy, if it were practicable, would be the most perfect government. Experience has proved that no position is more false than this. The ancient democracies, in which the people themselves deliberated, never possessed one good feature of government. Their very character was tyranny; their figure deformity.

Had every Athenian citizen been a Socrates, every Athenian assembly would still have been a mob.

I do not say that democracy has been more pernicious on the whole, and in the long run, than monarchy or aristocracy. Democracy has never been and never can be so durable as aristocracy or monarchy; but while it lasts, it is more bloody than either. Remember, democracy never lasts long. It soon wastes, exhausts, and murders itself. There never was a democracy yet that did not commit suicide. It is in vain to say that democracy is less vain, less proud, less selfish, less ambitious, or less avaricious than aristocracy or monarchy. It is not true, in fact, and nowhere appears in history. Those passions are the same in all men, under all forms of simple government, and when unchecked, produce the same effects of fraud, violence, and cruelty. When clear prospects are opened before vanity, pride, avarice, or ambition, for their easy gratification, it is hard for the most considerate philosophers and the most conscientious moralists to resist the temptation. replies.author: @DrCruel
replies.text:
No "redefinition" necessary. More like the process whereby a word eventually means how it is used. The Left and Right used to define a specific dichotomy - Leftists were in favor of redistribution and leavening of power (republicanism, democracy, universal suffrage, private property rights, etc) while the Right were monarchists in favor of absolute rights for a hereditary elite. Karl Marx tried to redefine the new Left as the working classes and the new Right as those who owned and controlled capital and the means of production, but this revisionism unraveled when Marxist socialists seized control of capital and the means of production, brutalized and exploited the working classes, then set themselves up as a hereditary socialist elite with absolutist powers. The paradox is, thus, this new Left became the old Right, declaring anyone and everyone who did oppose or might oppose them, or just happened on the menu for one reason or another, as the Right/far Right/alt-Right/etc.

British imperialism wasn't especially good, but it wasn't Leftist. The rampaging Mongols were not Leftists either. What is characteristic of the Left as we know it today is the secular religion of socialism, used as the justification for their sacred absolutist powers over everyone else. Because of socialism, and because their enemies are "capitalists" and "fascists," they claim the moral license to do whatever they like to whomever they like in pursuit of their revolution and the socialist greater good.- which invariably just so happens to be whatever is in the best interests of their specific faction of socialist capital-hoarding elite.

So it was with the Bolsheviks. So it is with the Maoists. So it was with the National Socialists also. No, I do not see the need to separate National Socialists as far as possible from other socialist groups that did very similar things for very similar reasons, using the same sort of socialist ideology as justification. I would object to someone claiming the Thuggees were socialists rather than Hindu. So also I object to socialists with the audacity to claim that National Socialists were, say, "end stage capitalists" or libertarians or Christian fanatics or anything else but the socialists that the National Socialists repeatedly claimed to be and which they in fact were.

Socialism once had lofty meaning in the 19th century. In the 21st century it has come to refer to a despotic scam. We are literally watching another empirical example of this odious scheme as it unfolds in Venezuela. No doubt in the future some eager and unscrupulous socialists will pretend Maduro's government wasn't socialist either, well after the fact. If I am still around at the time, I will be happy to remind them otherwise.

PS: I'm glad you realize that the National Socialists were "bad." One couldn't expect as much from a Left fascist activist in 1940. Progress may be slow at times, but it is inevitable.

replies.author: @DrCruel
replies.text:
Hitler used the fear of Bolshevism, and with good reason. The Bolsheviks had already tried to take over Germany; unfortunately for the Bolsheviks, the Spartacist uprising was crushed by German war veterans by 1919 and the Red Army's invasion of Poland was stopped at the Vistula in 1920 . Germans were terrified of the growing Bolshevik menace, enhanced by regular declarations and promises by the Bolsheviks that one they they would "liberate" Germany. Needless to say, turning to Hitler and his gangster socialist crew in their desperation was a Faustian bargain.

The Russian peasants were promised "Peace, Land and Bread" by Lenin, and bought into the lie. They instead were forced onto communal farms owned by the state, a form of serfdom which they rebelled against. In retaliation, the Bolsheviks made brutal war on them and deliberately starved millions to death. When the peasants were fighting and dying so that the Bolsheviks could overcome the White Armies, they did not realize they were signing their own death warrants. I don't expect they would have fought so hard if they knew how they would have been betrayed by the Bolsheviks, regardless of the blocking attachments that Trotsky used to herd them forward. So also, I don't expect the Germans would have been so enthusiastic about the National Socialists in 1933 if they knew what was in store for them in 1945. And so on.

Note also that the socialists helped Hitler when it suited their interests. The all-out German offensive against the French in 1940 would not have been possible without a National Socialist alliance with the Bolshevik socialists in 1939, but then the Bolsheviks had a few neighbors they wanted to crush and absorb into their empire as well. Like a shark, socialist regimes are always eating, and if they can't raid and absorb new victims they slowly starve to death.

PS: Again, socialism is a scam. It has nothing to do with empowering workers. It has nothing to do with liberating anyone. It's about socialists making themselves into aristocratic despots. Workers and management cooperate in some of the most successful firms in Germany, but this isn't "socialism," because the Bolshevik Empire threatened West Germany regardless, long after the Second World War, for being ruled by the "decadent bourgeoisie." So no, I don't believe socialist bullshit and propaganda, but this has nothing AT ALL to do with my sentiments regarding worker rights. In fact, I would go so far as to say one of my main reasons to oppose socialists is because I respect workers and worker rights. I do NOT respect the "right" of Bolsheviks to rob and kill business owners and enslave workers in gulags "because Marxism."

replies.author: @dribrom
replies.text:
Socialism is commonly regarded as an economic system that seeks to achieve equality among members of society. Communism, on the other hand, is both an economic system that seeks equality among members of society and a political ideology that advocates a classless and stateless society and rejects religion. It is regarded as a more extreme form of socialism.

Socialism and communism both adhere to the principle that the resources of the economy should be collectively owned by the public and controlled by a central organization. They differ, however, in the management and control of the economy. In socialism, the people themselves decide through communes or popularly elected councils on how the economy should work. This makes socialism a liberal system because majority of the people have a say on how the economy should be run. Communism, on the other hand, controls its economy through a single authoritarian party. It is thus characterized as conservative because the economy functions based on the decisions of a few.

The views of socialism and communism also differ in the distribution of wealth produced by the economy. Socialism supports the view that the goods and services produced should be dispensed based on the productivity of an individual. In contrast, communism believes that the wealth should be shared by the masses based on the needs of the individual.

There are two kinds of properties in socialism: (1) personal property that an individual can own and enjoy; and (2) industrial property that is dedicated for the use of producing society‚Äôs goods. Individuals, for example, can keep their digital cameras but cannot retain a factory that produces digital cameras. While personal properties can be kept, socialists make sure, however, that no private property will be used as an instrument for oppression and exploitation. In comparison, communism treats all goods and services as public property to be used and enjoyed by the entire populace.

Finally, socialism and communism differ in their views on capitalism. Socialists regard capitalism as a threat to equality and public interest. They believe, however, that there is no need to eliminate the capitalist class because it can be used as a good instrument in the transition to socialism as long as it is properly controlled. Socialists also believe that capitalism can exist in a socialist state and vice versa. From the point of view of the communists, capitalism must to be destroyed totally in order to give way to a classless society.

replies.author: @ForOrAgainstUs
replies.text: A really great way to avoid any agreement is to argue over labels.

replies.author: @ForOrAgainstUs
replies.text:
Actually, everyone. I was watching a ContraPoints video critiquing Jordan Peterson, how he uses the term "postmodern neomarxism" and that it's a contradiction in terms. They're labels, but they're not separate; they're together. I made up the analogy that if you saw someone kicking a baseball and they said they were playing a game called "baseball-soccer" you'd be right to point out that they are neither playing baseball nor soccer, but you wouldn't be so dense as to not understand what this person was saying. The same can be applied to postmodern neomarxism in the Contrapoints video and to the National Socialism of Hitler's Germany. Are there aspects of both Nationalism and Socialism in 1930s Germany? I think an easier case can be made if you don't try to strictly apply the definitions of labels to the words being used and try to be a bit more charitable. The fact is, when you argue over labels, you're avoiding discussing what is behind the cognitive shortcut of the label, and you will often cherry pick your favorite parts, which is kind of necessary. Secondly, when you hyphenate or portmanteau two different labels, the result is not going to be synonymous with either of those labels.

So yeah, you if you think this applies to you. If not, then not you.

author: @thesovietsage6688
text:
The Nazis were indisputably right-wing*


In the months after Hitler took power, SA and Gestapo agents went from door to door looking for Hitler‚Äôs enemies. They arrested Socialists, Communists, trade union leaders, and others who had spoken out against the Nazi party; some were murdered By the summer of 1933, the Nazi party was the only legal political party in Germany. Nearly all organized opposition to the regime had been eliminated. Democracy was dead in Germany.

However, the assumption that because the word ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù appeared in the party‚Äôs name and socialist words and ideas popped up in the writings and speeches of top Nazis then the Nazis must have been actual socialists i find this Mind-Numbingly naive and ahistorical. What the evidence shows, on the contrary, is that Nazi Party leaders paid mere lip service to socialist ideals on the way to achieving their one true goal: raw, right-wing totalitarian power

Sometimes the claim is handed about that the Nazis were a left-wing party on economic questions, perhaps because the Nazis were called ‚ÄúNational Socialist's‚Äù. This is flatly and completely wrong and a form of pseudo-historiography. Here‚Äôs why:

The Nazi party was built on right-wing voters and a right-wing support base

There are many disputes about the nature of Hitler‚Äôs voting base. What isn‚Äôt under dispute though is that prior to voting Nazi, Nazi voters voted for center-right and far-right parties, or didn‚Äôt vote at all. Support for the Nazis did not come from disaffected left-wing or center-left voters, but from right-wing voters frustrated with the existing parties of the right.
In my view this point alone is decisive. The meaning of right-wing and left-wing is not an ahistorical abstraction, it‚Äôs created by the behavior of people and institutions. The right-wing citizens of Germany implicitly recognized the Nazis as right-wing by voting for them, case closed

2. The Nazis literally invented privatization:
The Nazis were responsible for huge privatization programs. The extent of their privatization's was enormous, but it was particularly vast when compared with other countries at the time, who were generally moving in the opposite direction. The privatization's of Nazi Germany may indeed have been the first mass privatizations of public property in history and included ‚ÄúSteel, mining, banking, shipyard, ship-lines, and railways.‚Äù More on how Nazis bucked historical trends by privatizing when no one else was here: http://www.ub.edu/graap/nazi.pdf

3. Nazi policies greatly increased income inequality:

Income inequality spiked under Hitler, as was observed even at the time. More here: http://piketty.pse.ens.fr/.../RefsHistorical.../Sweezy39.pdf

4. Capital as a share of factor income also spiked under Hitler, at the expense of wages:

Factor income describes the division between the factors of production, with land receiving rent, capital receiving profit and labor receiving wages. The capital share, or profit as a proportion of total income, increased by about 50% in Nazi Germany and was much higher than the US‚Äôs capital share at the time. See the below graph from Capital in the Twenty-First Century reproduced in a Jacobin article by Corey Robin:
I‚Äôm sorry if there‚Äôs not much in the way of Belles-lettres here. If I am blunt it is for a purpose. The Nazis were right-wing. Anyone who tells you otherwise is wrong, much in the same way it is wrong to say that the world is flat, six-thousand years old, or made of cheese

replies.author: @pingas6941
replies.text: Whilst the Nazis did allow for some private businesses it should be noted that the Nazis set up the German labor front which gave the Nazi party control of much of Germany‚Äôs industry and workers. Having control over a country‚Äôs industry and workers mean that you control the means of production, and the government having control over the means of production is one of the core tenants of socialism. I should also not that Hitler arresting certain socialist or communist factions doesn‚Äôt necessarily make him right wing or not a socialist. In the USSR the Bolsheviks (who were undeniably left wing) arrested many communist/socialist groups who‚Äôs view of socialism they disagreed with, such as the Mensheviks. And Hitler making the Nazi party the only legal party in Germany doesn‚Äôt make him right wing either. In the USSR (still a very left wing regime) the communist party was the only legal party. Same goes for China, North Korea, and every other communist regime to ever exist. Literally every communist regime to ever exist has been an authoritarian one party police state, much like Nazi Germany was, and I think that we can both agree that communism is an exclusively left wing ideology.

replies.author: @johnhooyer3101
replies.text:
Americans kill Americans.  Yet to many in the outside world, apparently we're all center-right compared to them.  My understanding is that both highly favored government with a social engineering agenda, but the ultimate goals of said social engineering is different.  Communism seeks an equal, classless society, whereas Fascism sees hierarchy as beneficial for a more efficient society.  Communism seeks fairness, while Fascism seeks greatness.  One is international, the other is national.  Otherwise, it does still stand that both have government policies explicitly intervening in the social welfare to sculpt a specific social order.  In that sense, both are socialist.

Defining Nazism is a  complex affair.  I would consider it both progressive, because of its strong intervention in everyday life and ambitious goals, but also socially conservative, in that it wished to protect pre-existing norms for national identity.  However, it was not fiscally or governmentally conservative.  It was Right Wing in that it did not concern itself with redistributing a hierarchy (I'm going by the French definition of the Right).  It was highly liberal in its use of government, but it did not take an actual liberating view of human beings.  It was socialist in that it dictated the social order.

The funny thing is, when people claim that Nazism has things in common with Republicans or Democrats, nobody's entirely wrong.

replies.author: @johnhooyer3101
replies.text: Socialism is a very broad umbrella term, and it's hard to actually pinpoint a precise conventional meaning seeing as there are many political conventions that have defined it .  It's broad enough that it has a lot of application.  Most governments count as socialist in the most governments have a socio-economic agenda.  Socialism isn't necessarily the same thing as welfarism; it does not always redistribute from wealthy to proletariat.  It's basically any state where means of production are either owned or strongly influenced by the government/public.  I tend to veer from using the term "dictatorship" freely, for while it's supoosed to refer to a strong and tyrannical government, there's no universal consensus on where the line is drawn to define a government as dictatorial.  Americans do not consider their country to be a dictatorship, for example, but Canadians might disagree.  Actually, at any given point of time, about 50% of Americans will conveniently define their government as a dictatorship.  Therefore, I try to define governments by their structures and their political objectives.  "Socialist" tends to describe most governments throughout history, because as I've said, most governments do have objectives pertaining to establishing a desired socio-economic order.  Whether or not the desired outcome is a an efficient hierarchy or a classless society, I consider both to be socialism.

replies.author: @justnobody6064
replies.text: In short, in an economic socialist system, the society ( the people) control the flow of goods. In a political socialist system, the elected governnment regulates goods for the purpose of promoting equality. The Nazi party was a fascist system. Fascism is not socialism because the people have no say in how goods are distributed nor how leaders are elected, nor is there an onus on the government to create income equality. In a fascist society, it is everyone‚Äôs purpose to serve the government. You can find more vague definitions of socialism, but they are not particularly helpful when we try to classify a society as socialist. We usually say that socialist societies are somewhere in between communist and capitalist, even though just looking at those definitions, it could be used to describe countries under either system. Just quickly google ‚Äúdefinition of socialism‚Äù, it‚Äôs their definition I used.

author: @justinreid2947
text: This video was desperately needed and your content has been a Godsend due to the rise of far-right ideas here in the USA. One person my dad knows called single payer health care "Communism" so you have understand just how right-wing and ill-informed US society truly is. I've always known that the term "National Socialist" was a propaganda misdirection and that the Nazis were viciously anti-Marxist and anti-Socialist, but I would get into actual arguments with people about this who just see the word "Socialist" in the NSDAP name and jump to conclusions. Also people here think any expansion of government is "Socialist", which it isn't. Socialism is workers owning the means of production vs. Nazism where the state is the number priority in life and also that the Aryan race should dominate the planet. Those two aren't the same thing as Marx advocated the ultimate extinction of the state in the Communist Manifesto (and from what I know wasn't an anti-Semitic lunatic). And like you said capitalism remained throughout most of the Third Reich but always subservient to the needs of their racist agenda. This is a scary time in the USA where fear and hatred of the other have become mainstream and vast social inequities and government corruption dominate. Thank you again for clearing up the far-right lies.

replies.author: @perfidy1103
replies.text:
I said you were a low IQ, Fox News watching Trump supporter? News to me.

What's wrong with what you said? Firstly your statement that the progressive left is against free speech, and individual liberty is simply not true. I know, of course, what you're referring to when you talk of "suppression of speech": no-platforming. This is actually a very interesting question which free speech absolutists tend to overly simplify. Firstly, there's a difference of freedom of speech and entitlement to be platformed (this should be apparent, unless you're in favour of having random strangers have the right to come into your house in order to exercise their freedom of speech). That said, without a platforms freedom of speech is meaningless, and many universities are (at least in part) funded by the government (not certain how true this is in the US to be fair, but it's definitely true here in the UK) which raises questions on whether they can legitimately no-platform. For the former, despite their insistence on the contrary, the right wingers who claim their freedom of speech is being suppressed due to no-platforming at universities are being disingenuous since they inevitably do so using one of the many other platforms available to them (YouTube, Facebook, Twitter and, often, traditional media). As for the latter I'd argue that, since universities have limited resources for hosting speakers they will inevitably have to refuse some: the question is what the criteria for selecting who gets to speak are. The purpose of universities is, amongst other things, to encourage debate and discussion, and I'd argue that that's not the aim of people like, say, Milo Yiannopoulos. In these cases if a university decides not to host a speaker I'm not going to cry over their (in reality not) suppressed speech. However if there is a genuine discussion to be had, even if its on a topic many find unpleasant, I am broadly against no-platforming if for no other reason that it has the opposite effect i.e. it tends to promote the speaker. This transcript of a speech on the issue - https://www.currentaffairs.org/2018/03/transcript-of-davidson-college-speech - by Nathan Robinson is well worth a read.

What puzzles me is why such a big deal is made of this issue however. A handful of people who already have very large platforms available to them are being refused an, ultimately, very small platform at universities is worth coverage by the media, but the active suppression of voters by Republicans is not? 

"Which of those names I gave were not on the "left"?" Most of them. You can't trust the labels that authoritarian dictators adopt. Those who seek power will claim to be whatever happens to be expedient. Instead look at their actions. To call (most) of them leftists is simply ignorant of what the left believes. Ho Chi Minh is the outlier here. It's difficult to say what he would have been like as a peacetime ruler since he never got the chance. One thing worth reading is the Vietnamese declaration of independence (from France) see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proclamation_of_Independence_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam . Ask yourself whether, had the Cold War not been going on, would America have gotten involved.

As for your final point, I am not committed to being left, I am committed to whatever improves the lives of humans across the planet. It just so happens that, on the whole, this aligns with the left much more often than the right (at least to the best of my understanding). However this video was about debunking the idea that Hitler was a socialist when, by any sensible definition, Hitler was right wing. That's why the language of left and right is being used.

replies.author: @matthewstone9360
replies.text:
Perdify - first, thanks for your answer.  It's nice being able to go back and forth with someone who isn't just a pure troll. 

With regards to freedom of speech, it's absolutely true the greatest threat to it today is the progressive left (Bill Maher will confirm this for you, he is far from a right winger).  No, I don't think anyone has the right to a platform.  Twitter, Facebook, Google, Et Al. are private platforms and are offering you a service based on their own terms and conditions.  If you don't follow their conditions they have every right to remove you from their platform.  That's not speech suppression that is called a business operating in a free market with a right to their private intellectual property (like the old signs use to say "no shoes, no shirt, no service").  Which is the beauty of having something like the internet operating in a (mostly) free market.  People who get deplatformed have every opportunity to, right now at least, create their own platform and give them a place for their voice to be heard.  It may not be as easy as creating a Facebook page or a Youtube account but the opportunity is still there.  Which is also why the economics of the left (socialism, then communism) are rather frightening.  I'm sure that point could turn into a whole nother debate though....   

Suppression of platform is not what I'm talking about at all.  Universities that do open their stages up for "right wing" speakers frequently have students coming to the event who shout down speakers mid speech (Dave Rubin at University of  New Hampshire is a good recent example of this) (Side note, typically a university in the US that does host a "right wing" speaker typically has a student group paying the speaking fee.  The only thing the university provides is a space to host the event in.)  You will probably have this group of students chanting at some point "We're for free speech but this is hate speech" over the speaker.  Showing up to events and shouting people down because you don't like what they are saying is suppressing free speech.  It's not restricted to Universities either.  There have been multiple incidents just this year where Republican governmental officials and "right wing" speakers have been surrounded and shouted at while they are out eating at restaurants or other places where they are just living their lives.  You could say this is just a few unconnected events, except you have Democrat congresswoman Maxine Waters at a rally telling her supporters to surround Republicans when they see then at restaurants and gas stations to shout and intimidate them.  And don't get me started on Milo.  I detest trolls and he is one of the biggest.  If we are going to talk at least have principals and ideals you stand on that we can go back and forth on.  People like Milo have none and just say stuff for the purpose of riling people up.  

On top of issues above you also get endless speech policing throughout the media.  This has led comedians like Jerry Seinfeld, Chris Rock, and the aforementioned Bill Maher (all hard core "right wingers" that group is) to say comedy is going to die because of the "PC" culture.  It's not long before people start getting fired because they express a different opinion from the leadership of the company they work for.  Oh wait, I forgot that is already happening.  If you are a religious or political organization, I get it, your ideology is the job so if you have people that aren't on board with your organization's mission they probably shouldn't be there.  But when you are a tech company, you are going to fire people because their political opinions don't line up?  People afraid to talk about their political or religious ideologies because they may lose their job is suppression of speech and that is absolutely happening right now.      

"but the active suppression of voters by Republicans is not? "  I know you said you are in the UK so I'm going to put the same answer back on you that you gave to me, check your sources.  Seriously, what are your sources for this?  Where is this happening?  What are Republicans doing exactly to "suppress voters?"  Voting is more open and available to anyone in the US now more than anytime in the history of the world.  Seriously, there are government sponsored things such as early voting that happens in the US which is statistically proven to benefit Democrats.  Fact is you can't just spout out "voter suppression...Republican" you actually have to back it up, and when you do we can all arrest the people who are perpetrating it.  Until then it is an unfounded scare tactic designed to try to make people think "left good, right bad".  

"Which of those names I gave were not on the "left"?" Most of them"  - If that's what you think then you are rewriting history brother.  Everyone one of those men where self avowed communists.  Communism is internationally recognized as the far left side of the political spectrum. 

"As for your final point, I am not committed to being left, I am committed to whatever improves the lives of humans across the planet. It just so happens that, on the whole, this aligns with the left much more often than the right"  I'm with you on the principle, not so much on the execution friend.  I think we have the benefit of history to see how the traditional left/right positions on economics play out in people's lives.  Move more and more to the left and you end up with less free speech, less choices, less individual freedom (see Russia, China, North Korea for extreme examples).   Frankly, I don't think anyone should shack up with either ideological side (contrary to what you probably think about me after this discussion, I don't) but I think your starry eyed view of leftist ideology betrays what I think your honest desires are.  Ultimately that is where the heart of this discussion lies for me and how we ended up here from where we started.  

Hitler may have not been a true socialist and the communists of Europe at the time may have been his enemies but the fruits of communism are the same as facism, the wrapper just looks different.  "Facism-right to communism-left" is a false equivalency and Hitler had a lot more in common with the communists who shaped eastern Europe for nearly a century than he does with a "constitutional conservative" in the US.
